All right, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the power. So in this video I want to talk about the 1973 Mr Olympia, specifically Arnold Schwarzenegger's physique at that Olympia. And this would be the year that Arnold Schwarzenegger would actually break Sergio Aliva's record of winning three Olympias and this would be Arnold's fourth Olympia win. Winning in 1971, 72 and of course that year in 1973. So specifically the 1973 Olympia, I believe is Arnold Schwarzenegger's most shredded physique that he ever brought to the Olympia stage. Now the following year in 1974, most people would argue that 1974 was the biggest physique that Arnold ever brought to the Olympia stage. Many say 1974 is the only time the Arnold was over 250 pounds on stage. But in 1973 we saw the most shredded and arguably the best version of Arnold that we had ever seen. I mean everything about Arnold at this Olympia was just completely on point. Arnold wasn't really known for having the best legs he never has been, but in 1973 his conditioning was so good that the separation in his legs was amazing. And you've got to keep in mind the legs back in the 70s weren't like the legs that we see today. So the separation that Arnold had in his legs in 1973 was really a groundbreaking level of leg separation especially from the front. So I think the front double bicep pose tells a lot of the story about Arnold's conditioning in 1973, but I think probably the best pose is this pose you're looking at here. The most muscular pose from 1973. This pose right here really exemplifies how conditioned Arnold really was. The striations in the pecs arguably better than we've ever seen from Arnold's deep crazy striations in the pecs. The shoulders crazy striated. And I would also say that from a vascularity standpoint this could be the most vascular version of Arnold's words and I guess that we've ever seen. Just look at the thickness and the deepness of the veins that you can see in his biceps and that most muscular pose. Probably the thickest his veins have ever been in the most that they've ever stood out was in 1973. Now a couple interesting facts about the 1973 Mr Olympia number one would be the fact that Sergio Levo was originally scheduled to compete. But this was a show that he was actually to squallified from or barred from competing by the IFBB for competing in a rival organization known as the WBBG or the World Body Building Guild. And this was a promotion done by Dan Loury, who was one of the biggest rivals to Joe Weedre. So in 1972 Sergio Levo competed in the WBBG Mr Galaxy competition. And this was after the IFBB had implemented their non-sanction policy in 1991. So 1991 was the year of the IFBB said, okay, if you guys want to compete in other organizations, that's fine. But if you do so, you won't be able to compete at the Olympic. You can only be an IFBB pro body builder. You can't be a pro body builder in other organizations. The IFBB is it. So we could have seen Arnold and Sergio go head to head in 1973, but we actually didn't. So there was only three competitors at the 1973 Mr Olympia. You had Arnold Schwarzenegger, Franco Colombo, and of course serves New Bray. And another interesting fact about the 1973 Mr Olympia was this was one of the few years in body building where the prize money for the Olympia actually dropped from the previous year. So in 1972 the prize money was $1,000, then it would drop $250 down to $750 in 1973. So as we know Arnold Schwarzenegger won that show, Franco would take second and third new Bray would take the third place spot. So again, in my opinion, 1973 was one of the most shredded physics that Arnold ever brought. He had that hard, you know, but grainy and dense, crazy muscle that was just super shredded. Unlike anything we had ever seen from Arnold before. Arnold was typically known for coming in big and in some cases coming in soft, especially in those early mystery universe competitions that you won throughout the 60s. But at this particular show, we saw Arnold like we had never seen him before, extremely ripped, and extremely hard, and just striations and veins all over. So in my opinion, 1973, the most conditioned Arnold we ever saw let me know in the comments section below what you guys think, what year was Arnold's most conditioned physique. Please give the video a thumbs up, you enjoyed it, next time you're in power, signing out.

=== FILE: 1976： The First Olympia without Arnold [eW4kmvdhQPs].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's Time of Power. So I want to make a video today about the 1976 Mr. Olympia contest. Now you might be asking yourselves, what is the significance of the 1976 Mr. Olympia? Well, in the early 1970s, Arnold Schwarzenegger dominated the Olympia scene and was the most dominant Mr. Olympia in Olympia history at that point in time when he was first six Olympia titles from 1975 ending with the 1975 Mr. Olympia. Obviously the filming of Pumping Iron took place. Documenting the journey of Arnold Schwarzenegger Lou Fergnot and of course Serge New Bray to that 1975 Olympia stage. And of course as we all know in 1975, a lot of people thought that marked the end of an era because Arnold officially announced his retirement during the 1975 Mr. Olympia after he won that title. Now as we all know he would come back in 1980, but the following year in 1976 would be the first Mr. Olympia without Arnold Schwarzenegger. And that made things very, very interesting. Now before we dive into the 1976 Mr. Olympia, I want to rewind a little bit to the 1974 Mr. Olympia. Now the reason I want to do that is because in 1974, that was the first Mr. Olympia competition ever to have two different weight classes. The over 200 and of course the under 200. Now that fact is important because in 1976 you'd have the first winner of a Mr. Olympia that won the under 200 and then went on to win the overall the overall Olympia title by defeating a heavyweight or an over 200 pound body builder. So in 1976 not only was Arnold no longer in the over 200 division, but Lou Fergnot and Serge New Bray, who had previously been dominant members of the over 200, both of them were not in it as well. So all of the competitors in the over 200 division were brand new competitors to the Mr. Olympia and Ken Waller who won and Mike Katz who took second. Now you may remember both of those names from Pumping Iron. Now their journey was documented but was not their journey to the Mr. Olympia. It was their journey to a amateur show. In 1976 would be both of their first Olympias then in the under 200 pound category had Franco Colombo, Frank Zane, Ed Corny, Bill Grant and Boyer Coe, Bill Grant and Boyer Coe also competing in their first Mr. Olympia ever. So 1976 marked the end of an era and marked the end of the era of Arnold Schwarzenegger and it marked the beginning of an era of new body building champions. Particularly it marked the beginning of the under 200 body builder era. So from 1976 to 1979 the winner of the Mr. Olympia competition would be all under 200 pound body builder. So in 1976 of course you had Franco Colombo winning his first of two Mr. Olympias. So that was significant that Franco won his first title. But the following year 1977, 1978 and 1979 you had Frank Zane win his three Mr. Olympia titles. Frank Zane also an under 200 pound body builder. So the interesting thing here is that Arnold Schwarzenegger would come back in 1980 to compete in the 1980 Mr. Olympia and at the 1980 Mr. Olympia there were no weight classes. There was no over 200 there was no under 200. So the end of Arnold Schwarzenegger's body building career marked the beginning of the under 200 champion and then Arnold Schwarzenegger coming back in 1980 marked the end of the under 200 champions. I don't know what significance there is to that and if Arnold had anything to do with that that just happens to be the case. So that is the story of the significance of the 1976 Mr. Olympia. I've got a couple other very popular videos about some of the older Mr. Olympias as well and I'm planning on doing some more in the future. So stay tuned for those. Thank you guys for watching the video. I hope you enjoyed it. Please give this video a thumbs up if you did enjoy it. Next time of power signing out.

Alright, what's going on you guys Nick here with Nick's Family Power. So I wanted to do a more in-depth video on the new 2018 Mr. Olympia fan voting options. So if you didn't see my video yesterday, in an upcoming issue of muscle and fitness, they announced that in the 2018 Mr. Olympia, the fans will have the opportunity to vote for the Mr. Olympia winner. So they're saying essentially the fans will be an additional judge in the scores that the fans vote on are going to be entered in the actual competition results. So there's a couple of things I want to touch on in this video. Number one, how big of a say are fans actually going to have in the final decision? Is this going to be a game changer for the actual Mr. Olympia winner? Number two, they're going to be introducing something called the 2018 Mr. Olympia People's Champion. And this is something that's going to happen if the judges disagree with the fans in the decision of who's going to be the winner. The 2018 Mr. Olympia People's Champion will be crowned and that will be the person that the fans have chosen to be the winner of the Mr. Olympia. And that would bring me to the third thing I want to discuss and that is Kai Green. So Kai Green commented the post of this original article. He said, now's my chance. I mean, that raises a lot of speculation as the weather not Kai is going to compete at the 2018 Mr. Olympia because arguably you could say that Kai Green has always been the People's Champion. He's arguably the most popular bodybuilder today on social media. He's more popular than seven-time Mr. Olympia feel heath. He's always been in the fans opinion seemingly an uncrowned Mr. Olympia. So with this addition of this People's Champion fan voting option, could this be Kai Green's best opportunity to compete at the Mr. Olympia and possibly win the Mr. Olympia. So I'm going to cover all those points in this video. But mostly we're going to go through this article and talk about what this really means for the judging of the Mr. Olympia in 2018. So let's start with the bombshells mentioned in this article. So bombshell number one. For the first time in the history of Mr. Olympia and professional bodybuilding, fans will judge each competitor and rank them and those scores will count in the official decision. Yes, you and all the other fans at the Oerlinges Arena will have a voice in deciding who will be the next Mr. Olympia. The fans collectively will be in effect another judge at the table at Friday night's pre-judging and Saturday night's finals. So what does this mean really for the fan? So the first thing that I noticed right away is it's addressing specifically the fans are going to be in attendance not the fans online and not the fans watching the live stream only fans that are there watching live in person. That's a very important thing to note because a lot of the concern that I saw on my last video with people thinking this was a bad idea and I was them thinking all these internet trolls out there are going to try to throw the results because they hate fill Heath because they hate a certain body builder that are just going to vote for anybody besides Phil to kind of throw the results because it's just internet trolls. I think this is going to eliminate a lot of that bias because honestly I think all the people or the majority of the people that are willing to pay for a ticket to go to the actual Mr. Olympia, these are serious body-building fans for the most part, these are not internet trolls, these are people that are serious about body-building and for the most part, I think they wouldn't be very biased or have any crazy votes in their judging of the Olympia and as Dave Palombo mentioned in his video on this topic, if there was any crazy wild voting, that score would most likely be thrown out because the highest score in the lowest score is always thrown out in body-building judging. So that's the first point, no this isn't going to be like American Idol, it's not going to be all the fans at home or casting a vote, it doesn't seem like it's going to be anything like that but of course we're waiting to see more details as we get, you know, as more information is released. But no I don't think this is going to be like an online voting competition where it's going to be okay everybody at home get out your cell phones and text the winner to this number, I don't think that's going to be what this is at all. I think, you know, essentially it's going to be more of a publicity stunt for the Mr. Olympia, I think like I said, they're reacting to the reaction that they got last year. Last year a lot of fans were upset, a lot of fans disagreed with the judging, but I think the people who run the Olympia noticed that, they're starting to pay attention to social media, they're starting to pay attention to what the fans have to say and they're wanted to make a response to that in a way that would seemingly give the fans some control over the results. Now as far as the actual Mr. Olympia being crowned, will this fan judging completely change a game and honestly it probably won't. The fans effectively still won't be picking who wins the Mr. Olympia. Now maybe if it comes down to a close one or two point decision having the fans as an additional judge, that could actually change the results. If you have all the judges, all their votes are in and it comes down to a one point decision from all the actual judges, then you have the fan vote come in. That could decide the result of the show. But again, if you look at it, the judges are going to outnumber the fan vote. So really it's always going to be the judges decision that goes for the final Mr. Olympia result, but that's why they have that 2018 Mr. Olympia people's champion. They're saying if the judges and the fans don't agree and all the judges vote for one guy and the fans vote for another and it's not a close decision, the people that are the person that the fan votes for that will be the 2018 Mr. Olympia people's champion. So let's go ahead and address the second bombshell here. Olympia bombshell number two. Judges points will be available to the public at the Orleans Arena before Saturday night's finals so you can see the competitor score before he steps on the Olympia stage. So what that means is the pre-judging results are going to be visible to the people and attendance so you can look at those results and make assessments based on how the competitors were judged or pre-judging before they go into the night show and cast their votes. So let's get the bombshell number three and I think this is most pertinent to Kai Green potentially doing the Mr. Olympia. So Olympia bombshell number three, if the fans pick a different winner than the judges, that competitor will be crowned the 2018 Mr. Olympia people's champion. You can think I have to be pro league president Jim Manion and AMI CEO chairman and president David J. Pecker for these developments. Jim feels that our fans are more than just spectators. They live the body building and fitness lifestyle and many compete or have competed. This makes some experts and they deserve a say. And David believes that empowering the fans so they are an active participant will take the event to a whole new level. That's it for now but stay tuned because I guarantee we will have more game changers as we approach the 2018 Mr. Olympia. So most likely number one this is just something that they're testing out. They want the fans to feel more involved and I think this is a good thing overall. I mean they're responding to last year the criticism that they got. I think this is better than having no answer at all or having no response at all. They're at least acknowledging the fans and acknowledging that there was a difference of opinion last year. So a lot of people felt this was going to lead to a lot of bias. This might be a bad idea but I think it's good at least they're trying to recognize that they want the fans to have a voice. So that brings me to Kai Green here. Obviously Kai has always kind of been the people's champion. He's always been a fan favorite. So typically when Phil and Kai go head ahead, Phil usually gets a straight you know all across the board. The votes for first place. So I think the people that organized this new rule took a safe bet here. For the most part the fan vote isn't going to have any major impact on the actual crowning of the Mr. Olympia but it's going to give the fans the feeling that they have some kind of say. And then the body builder in the challenge round could pick the pose that they compete against. So let's say you're going to get someone that has a week front double bicep and you have a strong front double bicep rather than hitting a last bread you can pick the pose to your advantage. And that's what the challenge round essentially was. But that only lasted a year. So this could just be a thing that they're testing out. It could be a one time thing. It might go horrible. So after pre-judging it was pretty clear that it was going to be between Nathan De Asch and Juan Morell. I myself thought Nathan De Asch had the edge after pre-judging and that turned out to be the case. And Nathan De Asch would win the 2018 New York Pro, beating Juan Morell who took second Justin Luis Rodriguez who took third and Josh Wade who took fourth and then John Delarosa coming in fifth place. Now although this was a pretty deep line up there were 26 IFPB Pro men's open body builders competing. It wasn't the most impressive or really that deep line up. There were some big names on there but really conditioning turned out to be an issue for a lot of guys, including a little bi-Eki, a keen William who I expected a little bit more from. And even some of the guys who placed in the top five, they're conditioning left a little bit to be desired. So it wasn't really the top best of the best. I don't think a whole lot of these guys were really competing at 110%. Some of these guys were maybe more like 90, 95%. But I still think Nathan De Asch who won the show did look incredible and did deserve that win. Nathan De Asch is going to be one of the fastest rising stars in body building. He's got an incredible physique. He's got crazy density and freakyness to him. He's just really complete. Now honestly, I actually think this was a really good move for Regan Grimes. I think number one, he looked incredible. But I really don't think he looked small or flat or depleted or any of that. I think the amount of weight and muscle that he had on his frame for this show was a good amount of weight, a good amount of muscle. And he really pulled it off very, very well in my opinion. And again, this was a very brave and very bold move for him to do a show like this and to make a jump like this because he really had no idea what to expect. I mean, this guy's never competed in classic before. He was used to men's open body building. He jumps in classic, you know, basically an overnight decision. And wins a very high level classic physique pro show. So my hats off to Regan Grimes for winning this show. I think it was very impressive. They're not looking for aesthetics. They're not really looking for the smallest waste. They're not really looking for the prettiest physique. 212 has always kind of been a battle of the freakyist, and Narlias, who has the most muscle on their frame. And a lot of those guys are 5 foot 5 and under. Now Steve Lourious is 5 foot 10, about 210 pounds. So when you're going up against the guy that's 5354, that weighs 210 pounds, and you're 6, 7 inches taller than them at the same weight, they're going to look significantly more muscular than you. If you take 455 for five reps and say that's 85% of his one rep max, then theoretically his flat bench should be 630 pounds for one rep. You would rarely see a photo of Arnold Schwarzenegger fat. You would rarely see a photo of Franco Colombo fat. And that's because they never really were fat. They believed in staying lean year round. Nowadays, you see guys pushing 300 pounds even over 300 pounds in the off season nowadays. You see guys pushing 330 and according to some people, big, ramen even pushes 350 in the off season. Because they don't have to do a crazy cut at the end of the year or right before a competition to meet a certain weight limit. So I think it's going to keep these guys relatively lean all year. === FILE: Arnold Schwarzenegger： The Austrian Oak [VjjGZeBQDbs].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys, Nick here with Nick Steppenpire. So in this video we're going to do a complete biography on who some considered to be the greatest bodybuilder of all time Arnold Schwarzenegger. Now as a bodybuilder, Arnold Schwarzenegger was a three-time pro-Mrs. Universe, a seven-time Mr. Olympia. He would go on to become the 30-a-a-a-f Governor of California, a movie star, with a net worth of over $400 million. He would serve as the chair of the president's council of physical fitness and sports from 1993. And he became one of the biggest bodybuilding promoters of all time when he started the Arnold Schwarzenegger Classic in 1989. Which is really the only bodybuilding competition to this day that could rival the title of Mr. Olympia. So Arnold Schwarzenegger was born on July 30, 1947 near Graus Austria. His father was the chief of police there and his father also voluntarily joined the Nazi Party during World War II. Arnold would go on to say later in life that he didn't have an easy childhood and his father was pretty rough on him. And what essentially say that he was abused by his father physically? However, his father would be the one that inspired him to start weight training at the age of 15 when he picked up his first barbell set back in 1960. So if he fast forward to 1965, Arnold Schwarzenegger was forced to serve in the Austrian army. It was just a duty that was required of everybody over the age of 18 at that point in time. Now, also in 1965, Arnold would compete in the junior Mr. Europe competition. And this would be the first bodybuilding competition that he would win. But he would win it at a cost. Because the competing that competition, he actually went AWOL from the military to compete. And then he served a weak and military prison as a result of that. So if he fast forward to Arnold Schwarzenegger's first ever Mr. Universe competition in 1966, this would be the first of three times that Arnold would be defeated on a bodybuilding stage. So in 1966, he was runner up at that Year's Mystery Universe taking second to a bodybuilder by the name of Chat Yorden. Who to this day claims he was a lifetime natural bodybuilder. Now in addition to Chat Yorden as we know, Arnold will go on to be defeated by Frank Xane at the Mystery Universe competition in 1968, and then by Sergio Aliva at the Mr. Alimpia in 1969. So even though Arnold didn't win the 1966 Mr. Universe, this was still a very critical moment for Arnold Schwarzenegger's bodybuilding career. It was at this 1966 Universe competition that Arnold was discovered by a man by the name of Wag Benz. Who was actually a judge at that Year's Mystery Universe. So while a lot of credit goes to Joe Weeder for being in the guy that, quote unquote, discovered Arnold, Wag Benz was really the first guy that noticed the potential that Arnold had at that 1966 Mr. Universe. And invited Arnold to come back to London with him and stay with him and train him for the next Year's Mystery Universe competition in 1967, which Arnold would actually go on to win due to Wag Benz training. And that Universe win would make Arnold the youngest ever at that time to win the Mystery Universe title at the age of 20 years old. So talking about Wag Benz, I want to talk about another guy that really had a major influence on Arnold Schwarzenegger's career and really influenced introducing him to Joe Weeder. So this man's name was Albert Buesek. So we talked earlier about that 1965 Junior Mr. Europe competition that Arnold competed in. So the promoter of that show was a man named Albert Buesek. And Albert Buesek was a personal friend of Joe Weeder. So Albert Buesek took immediate notice of Arnold after that 1965 competition. He took Arnold out to dinner after that show and they talked about his hopes and dreams of moving to America and becoming this big body building star. Then in 1966 Arnold went on to compete in that Mystery Universe competition. And that's where Albert Buesek told Joe Weeder about Arnold after that Universe second place finished. So Albert Buesek was constantly in Joe Weeder's ear telling him about this great guy from Europe. This Arnold Schwarzenegger that had all this potential in body building. And even 1967 went Arnold would win that Mystery Universe. Joe Weeder still hadn't made the offer yet to bring Arnold over to the United States. So after that 1967 Universe went Albert Buesek owned a magazine called the Sport Review magazine. And he would put Arnold on the cover of that magazine and shortly after that, him and Joe Weeder would have a sit down conversation in 1968 in Dusseldorf, Germany discussing the possibility of bringing Arnold over to the United States. So after that sit down, Joe Weeder decided to offer Arnold a paid invitation, a paid trip to the 1968 IFBB Mystery Universe competition, which was held in Miami, Florida. So history will show that Arnold actually lost that 1968 Mystery Universe in Miami, Florida, and he lost it to Frank Zane. But it was that loss actually that got Joe Weeder's attention. Because Arnold came in very big, very full. But the conditioning wasn't quite there. He hadn't really refined himself yet, but Frank Zane obviously is known for coming in very ripped and very shredded. And that's how Frank Zane won. So upon seeing this massive Arnold Schwarzenegger, Joe Weeder decided, okay, if we refine this guy, we show this guy how to get lean and get into his best shape. This guy has some serious potential. So that's actually what caused Joe Weeder to take Arnold under his wing, was seeing him lose the Frank Zane and knowing that Arnold could do so much better. So after that 68 Universe, Joe Weeder offered Arnold his first contract and invited him to come live in California and begin training their goals, Jim Venice, and living in America full time. So after moving to America Arnold would go on to win the 1969 Mystery Universe and also the 1969 Navum Mystery Universe. And then he would go on to compete at the 1969 Mystery Olympia, his Olympia debut, which was held in New York. And as history will show, he took second to Sergio Aliva, who was the reigning Mystery Olympia at that time, but Arnold would come back in 1970 to take the victory. Now the interesting thing about that was also in 1970, he would go to compete at the Mr World Competition, the AAU Mr World. So not an IFPB show. So outside of the IFPB, him and Sergio would go head to head at this Mr World. And he would actually defeat Sergio even for the first time prior to the Mr Olympia. Obviously generating a lot of hype and a lot of excitement going into that 1970 Olympia, that the Olympia Champion had been defeated before the Olympia. So Arnold would come back to New York at the 1970 Mr Olympia and defeat Frank Zane and begin his reign as seven-time Mr Olympia. So the following year in 1971, that would be where Arnold Schwarzenegger was the only competitor at the Mr Olympia. Now 1971 was the year that the IFPB introduced their non-sanction policy in the body building. So the IFPB essentially is the pro-body building organization founded by Joe Weater. Now at that time, there were a couple rival body building federations such as Naba. As I mentioned earlier, there was an IFPB Mystery Universe and a Naba Mystery Universe. So at the time, the Naba Mystery Universe was really one of the highest titles you could win as a body builder. And Joe Weater was really looking to monopolize the IFPB and make it really the only game in town in terms of being the best place to compete. He wanted the Mr Olympia to be the most prized title in body building. So the way he did that was in 1971, he said, okay, if you're an IFPB body builder and you go over and compete in Naba, you're going to be disqualified from competing at my Mr Olympia. So at the 1971 Olympia, Sergio Leva and Franco Colombo were both scheduled to compete, but they were both the Squallified for competing in rival organizations. But interestingly enough, they were both still allowed to guess pose at that 1971 Mr Olympia. So in 1972, Sergio Leva would be allowed back to the Mr Olympia competition. And him and Arnold would go head-to-head for the final time, and Arnold would come out on top winning that show. And Sergio Leva was actually so disgruntled that he took second after the show. He claimed the competition was rigged and he would not return to the Mr Olympia until almost a decade later when Arnold was done competing. So of course Arnold would go on to win the 1973-74 and 75 Mr Olympia. And as many of you know, the 75 Mr Olympia was the Olympia that was documented in the DocuDrama Pumping Iron, which was released in 1977. Now many people think that pumping iron was actually Arnold's first film, but in fact it wasn't. There was a film prior to that 1976 called Stay Hungry, which also starred Jeff Bridges in Arnold Schwarzenegger. It was like a secondary character in that movie, but even before Stay Hungry, Arnold actually did have a movie role in 1969 as Hercules. Now the interesting thing about that Hercules movie role is it was given away as a prize for winning that 1969 Mr Universe. Now even though Arnold's voice was dubbed over for the majority of the movie because of his accent, it was still a major movie role for a young Arnold Schwarzenegger that really propelled his career as a possible film star. So during that 1975 Mr Olympia that was documented in Pumping Iron, during his victory speech after winning that Olympia, Arnold retired from bodybuilding and said he was going to pursue his career in Hollywood. But as we all know Arnold would be back in 1980 to do the 1980 Mr Olympia and get that seventh title controversially mine. So the 1980 Mr Olympia is widely considered to be one of the most controversial bodybuilding decisions in history. I'm due to the fact that Arnold claimed he only trained for eight weeks for this show. And his training for that Olympia actually coincided with his training for his movie role in Conan the Barbarian, which would come out in 1982. Now let's talk about one of the main reasons why this decision was controversial. So after retiring as a bodybuilder in 1975, Arnold would go on to be a promoter of bodybuilding content. Specifically a promoter of the Mr Olympia, which back in the late 70s was actually held in Columbus, Ohio, and Arnold co-promoted the Olympia with his business partner and associate Jim Lorimer. So for the three years prior to his comeback to the Olympia stage as a competitor, Arnold Schwarzenegger was actually one of the promoters of that very same competition. So many people thought to show was then rigged in his favor because obviously being a promoter, he knew pretty much everybody involved with the Mr Olympia. So Arnold would end up winning that 1980 Mr Olympia beating Chris Dickerson who took second and Frank Zane, who was the returning champion from 1979, would take third, Boyer Co and Mike Menser would tie for fourth, and Menser ended up receiving fifth place as a result of that tie, and Mike Menser was arguably the most outspoken of how fix this Olympia was, and one of the most disappointed in that result. He would go on to Boycott the 1981 Mr Olympia, but he was not alone in that decision. Boyer Co and Roger Walker would also Boycott the 1981 Mr Olympia as a result of this show. Now another interesting tip about this 1980 Mr Olympia that speaks to the controversial nature of the result was that CBS actually came to this Olympia and filmed it for television, but after they saw the result, they thought it was so clearly controversial and so clearly rigged for Arnold, they ended up not airing it on TV. And that would be the last Mr Olympia competition ever filmed by an American broadcast television network. So during the 80s that would be Arnold's primary heyday as an action star in Hollywood starring as Conan the barbarian, the Terminator, Commando, here's in Predator, all the major movies that Arnold was in were primarily during the 80s. So fast forward to 1989, that's the year the Arnold Schwarzenegger decided to found the Arnold Sports Festival with the Arnold Classic as we know it today. And the same person that he teamed up with to promote the Olympia back in the late 70s, Jim Lorimer, was the same person he teamed up with to found this Arnold Classic. So back in 1989 Arnold and Jim Lorimer made this decision on a handshake that they would promote to show the Arnold Classic it would be held in Columbus Ohio and has been held there ever since for the past 30 years. And has been one of the most popular and most successful bodybuilding competitions in history further cementing Arnold Schwarzenegger's legacy as one of the greatest and most influential bodybuilders of all time. Now it was one year after that first Arnold Classic that Arnold would begin his career as the chairman of the president's council on physical fitness and that would really begin his career in politics and that would last from 1990 to 1993. Now fast forward 10 years and several more action movies from that point Arnold would become the 38th governor of California. He would serve 2 terms from January 2003 to January 3rd 2011. Now later that year in 2011 I think it was May of that year. Arnold and his wife Maria Schreiber would go through their separation after 25 years of marriage. It was widely publicized on the news that Arnold Schwarzenegger had a child with their housekeeper while he and Maria Schreiber were still married so that was a major moment in Arnold's life. And then most recently in 2018 Arnold Schwarzenegger underwent emergency open heart surgery. And this was because he was born with a bicuspid aortic valve which he had replaced back in 1997. But in March of 2018 he had to undergo emergency open heart surgery to repair that. And now at the age of 70 years old Schwarzenegger is on the road to recovery and he is doing well. So I hope you guys enjoyed that little mini documentary. Please give this video a thumbs up if you want to see more and please subscribe to this channel if you want to see more videos just like this. Now of course this progress picture just like it does every year has Instagram a buzz with the possibility of Big Rami winning the 2018 Mr. Olympia. So if you guys want to take a guess at how Big Rami looked, well he looked big. Just like he does every year and that's why his nickname is Big Rami. Every single year going into the Mr. Olympia, this similar thing happens and I say this time and time again, you know every year about this point there's a photo of Big Rami that gets released where he's looking big. He's always looking big. I mean you can't take that away from him. He's huge. He's the biggest bodybuilder on the Olympia stage by far. The freakyest bodybuilder arguably on the Olympia stage by far and probably one of the biggest bodybuilders we've ever seen. So usually in the off season he looks very big. Usually during his prep, he looks very big. I'm not surprised at all to see him post a picture during his prep for the Olympia where he's looking very big. So what I want to see from Big Rami this year, if he's looking to win the Mr. Olympia, is a different Big Rami during his prep. So if every single year we see photos of Big Rami during his prep looking big and every single year Big Rami doesn't seem to be able to win the Olympia, all of those years that he looks big, something's got to give. So obviously Big Rami doesn't need to get any bigger. He's already big. It's easy for him to be big. But we need to see, his big Rami shredded to the bone 12 weeks out from the Mr. Olympia and still being big at the same time, not just being big. So a big Rami had posted a picture today and he was diced, had cross striations and his quads. He was vascular all over his body. Then I would say, wow, I mean this is a different Big Rami. This is a Big Rami that we're not used to seeing because we've already seen Big Rami looking big. We've already seen offseason Big Rami. What we haven't seen is a Big Rami three months out of the Mr. Olympia. That's already shredded to the bone. Which in my opinion is the main reason why you're not seeing Big Rami win the Mr. Olympia. He can't come in with that level of conditioning that I think he needs to win the Olympia. Obviously like I said, he's the biggest body builder on stage, the freakyest body builder on stage. But he's almost never, well he never has been the most conditioned body builder on stage at the Mr. Olympia. So it is true that starting in 2013, all of Big Rami's Mr. Olympia play things have improved every single year he's competed at the Olympia. So a lot of people are speculating he's going to move up again this year and he's going to win the Mr. Olympia. But my question to you guys is just because Big Rami moves up in place every year. Does that mean he's bringing a better package every year? Or does that mean the other guys are coming in off each year allowing him to move up? Because honestly, I think like 2015, 2016 Big Rami was pretty much the best Big Rami that we'd ever seen in terms of conditioning and hardness and fullness. And I think from that 2015 to 2016 physique, he hasn't really gotten better since then. I think that was really the pinnacle of Big Rami. So I think he needs to improve upon that 2015, 2016 physique this year at the 2018 Mr. Olympia. Because in 2017 something just look off to me about Big Rami. === FILE: Bodybuilders on Instagram Vs Real Life [bkrGiASFRYw].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here in Next Time of Power. So I'm going to make a video about a bodybuilder specifically, Carlito XXL, who's kind of an Instagram star right now. And his primary claim to fame is his seemingly, you know, extreme vascularity, and also seemingly his extreme size. So the specific topic that I wanted to address in this video was kind of Instagram versus reality. I mean the ability of bodybuilders to kind of manipulate the lighting, the angles, the filters. To alter the way their physique actually look in real life, to the point where they look like a completely different person in their pictures, then they will look if you see them on stage or if you see them in person. So this isn't even addressing the possibility of photoshopping the pictures, adding size to the muscle, adding roundness and fullness. This is simply just addressing, you know, the angles, the lighting, and the filters that come with Instagram. The photoshopping is a whole other thing. But honestly, I don't know that Carlito XXL is doing that. It really just looks more so like he's mastering the angles. It's always under perfect lighting, and it's always filtered, you know, to the maximum. So the point to all this is I feel like a lot of people see these Instagram stars, these social media sensations that post these, you know, sensational pictures of their physique, of their physique, so a larger than life, you know, freaker than, you know, any possible real physique. And people think these guys are like God's man, like they have unattainable physique, like they're just on this next level type of, when really all it is, this filters enlightening in the perfect angle. I've said this many times in the comment section of my own pictures. Fitness is 99% good lighting in good angles. You can be a top six Mr. Olympia contender, but if you have a bad photo taken of you in the wrong lighting, you can look soft and flat and almost look like an NPC level body builder, and the reverse is also true. You can be kind of a half decent, you know, NPC body builder, and you can look like Mr. Olympia on Instagram by manipulating your photos to the extent of just making yourself look freaky. So the point here is just don't let yourself be easily deceived. I think a lot of people see these guys on Instagram and they're like, man, how's this guy not even an IFBB pro? How's this guy not Mr. Olympia yet? And the simple reason is, you know, it's all manipulation. Everything is photo manipulation. And what you'll actually see is the best of the best pro body builders, you can tell they don't even put a filter on their picture, they don't sharpen their picture, they don't change the saturation, they don't have to put, you know, a certain side angle to make their arm look bigger, they will pose straightforward from the front, no filters, and they will still look incredible. So that is the mark of a true champion, I'm going to true IFBB pro. And just for comparison purposes throughout this video, I've thrown in, you know, pictures of Carlydo XXL on his Instagram versus pictures of him at his last body building show in the NPC, where he did actually do very well. He has a great physique, there's no doubt about it. I mean, he won the light heavyweight division of the last show that he did, but that being said, even though he has a great NPC physique, his physique doesn't look anywhere near the way that it looks in his Instagram pictures with all these angles lighting and manipulation. So the point there is man, just don't believe the hype. And I'm not even accusing this guy a photo shop or even doing anything wrong. I mean, the majority of the fitness industry is doing this. And that's not to say that he's doing something wrong, but as to say that, you know, we should be aware that a lot of people are doing this. This is the way it is. So when you see these crazy photos and crazy physique on Instagram, you got to keep in mind a large percentage of this is lighting and angles and it's not actually disinsane physique. It's really more mastery of photography than it is mastery of body building, you know, in 2018, that seems to be what it's all about. So let me know what you guys think in the comments section below. Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's time to power. So in this video I wanted to address the topic of body building today, modern body building, is the standard for conditioning starting to slip. And for some of my international fans, I get this question a lot. What this conditioning mean, conditioning is how lean the body builder is, how ripped or shredded, how visible their lines and cuts are in their muscle, how much or how little body fat they have or water they have, mostly just how sharp and shredded they look as what conditioning means. And recently from 2017 to 2018, there's been a lot of controversy regarding the level of conditioning, especially if some of the winners of some major body building shows. In particular, it kind of started with the 2017 Mr. Olympia. A lot of people were upset about the fact that Phil Heath won that show, having a gut and being significantly off for Phil Heath, his conditioning wasn't as good as it usually is. I mean, his midsection obviously, watery, bloated and had a very visible gut on stage. So that kind of began the, you know, the really scrutiny on the conditioning of the body builders and in modern times. And then recently, this 2018 body building season, this is basically the Olympia qualification series where all the pro shows are pretty much every week of body builders trying to win a show or get enough points to qualify for the Mr. Olympia. Obviously, the biggest of which was the New York pro a couple weeks ago. I mean, the focus of a lot of people's criticism was the conditioning of all the guys. And the New York pro line up saying they were all pretty much lacking in conditioning. I'll be it. I think the lighting definitely played a factor in these guys looking off. And has the standard for conditioning dropped and is that the reason why they're not trying as hard to be conditioned? Do they know or do they think the judges are looking mostly at size and muscularity. And conditioning is kind of an afterthought to that. So the goal is to come in big and full and then if they happen to be conditioned, that's great. Is that the reason why these guys are coming in off at a lot of these shows? And that seems to be the case. Because a lot of these shows, they're rewarding guys that are coming in off. But they're coming in big and full and they still place well. Now, in Cedric's case, that obviously did not happen because the judges are used to seeing a much better Cedric. They've seen an Arnold Classic winning Cedric. They've seen a top Olympian Cedric. So in Cedric comes in off, he doesn't get rewarded. But bigger guys, an example here would be big ramen. I mean, big ramen is a guy that he's got such freaky size. But he almost never never comes in with crazy conditioning. Almost never. Especially at the Olympia. Honestly, I think in 2017, I don't know if big ramen deserved that second place finish. But again, I think he got rewarded with that second place spot because he did have that size. He did have that fullness. He just did have that crazy overall muscularity that the judges seem to be rewarding. So this is why guys like me and a lot of fans of the sport seem to really love this classic physique division because the emphasis seems to be mostly on conditioning. These guys are weight restricted by how tall they are. And the goal of that weight restriction is to prevent these guys from getting too big to where they can't come in with condition. These guys almost have to come in condition because they struggle to make these weight limits. So when people get all excited about classic physique and people will rag on it and say, you know, we want to see the big mass monsters, we want to see the freaks. This is why we're getting excited about it because I think it's honestly going to bring about a change in the sport. This weight restriction again is almost requiring guys to come in crazy condition. And then if you combine that with the idea of classic poses, classic presentation, symmetry, focus on conditioning and shape and structure. And basically throwing the idea of who's the most muscular guy out of the window. It's basically who is the most well-presented guy. Who's the most conditioned guy. Who has the best flow lines and structure of their physique. And that's what bodybuilding really was in the 70s and 80s. There were no real mass monsters back then. And that's why a lot of people say that Dorian Yates ushered in the era of the mass monster because he was really one of the first guys to have that type of physique. Before that, it was about aesthetics and posing and presentation. And that's why you had a smaller guy like Frank Xing and win three Olympias against guys that were much bigger than him. I'm so that's the main point that I want to stress is I think the mentality is shifting for a lot of reasons. Number one, I think is health. I think a lot of these guys are looking for a healthier way to be pro body builders and classic physique offers that option. You can, you don't have to get his big. It's not going to put as much stress on your body. You don't have to take as many or as much drugs, eat as much food. Train this heavy, put as much stress on your body as an open body builder that weighs, you know, 300 plus pounds in the off season. Then you've got to cut down a tremendous amount of weight. These guys in classic, they mostly walk around year round at a pretty lean body weight because they have to make this weight class. So there's no crazy fluctuation with these classic physique guys like there are men's open body builders. You see some of these guys, big ramen included, getting up to weights like 350 pounds in the off season, then they have to shed 50 pounds to make it to the stage. So not only are they carrying this crazy amount of body weight, then they have to go back down and lose a crazy amount of body weight. Then for the next off season, they'll do the same thing and walk back up. And this roller coaster of up and down weight is horrible for the body. So number one, I think the mentality is shifting because of health. Classic physique is the clearly healthier option. And number two, it's the bigger guys that tend to have these severe health problems in die. I mean, look at Dallas Macarver, one of the biggest body builders of this generation, 300 plus pound guy in the off season. I think he was 280s or 290s on stage. I think number two, it's just not becoming attainable or aesthetic or pretty to look at. People are starting to say, okay, we've seen enough giant guys. We know it can be done. But can these guys get conditioned? We don't want to see just big guy after big guy coming in with a gut, coming in with bad conditioning. We've seen enough of that. We want to see some guys that are shredded to the bone. And we're not seeing that. We're repeatedly getting these soft guys, these watery guys, these bubble guts over and over and over again. And people want to see something different. They want to see a sharp physique. They want to see a conditioned, lean shredded physique. They want to see lines. They want to see striations. As we all know, Dallas and the carver recently passed away in 2017. But I wanted to make kind of a tribute video going over some of his playsings. I'm talking about some of the things that he was able to achieve during the short bodybuilding career that he had. I'm in early his transformation because his bodybuilding career was so short. But he was able to transform his physique to such an extent. It's one of the most impressive transformations from amateur to pro. Arguably in the history of bodybuilding and such a short amount of time. He was also one of the youngest bodybuilders ever to turn pro earning his pro card at 21. But not only that, but he was one of the youngest bodybuilders ever to turn pro at the young age of 21 years old. And it wasn't just his age that was impressive. It was the fact that it was his third bodybuilding show ever that he turned pro at his third competition ever competing in his novice show. His second show he would qualify for the North Americans and his third show. He would go to the North Americans and win his pro card winning the overall. And the super heavyweight class at 21 years old. So one of the standout points that Dallas was known for during his competitive pro career was his sheer amount of muscle mass standing at six foot one getting up to about 350 pounds in the off season. Dallas was certainly one of the biggest if not the biggest bodybuilder on the pro circuit period. And next to guys like Big Rami. Now Dallas, my car for my opinion was a guy that was meant to be a big bodybuilder. I mean, this guy during his football career in high school was a guy that was always close to 300 pounds and over 300 pounds as a high schooler playing football. Now as I mentioned before, Dallas actually had a very short pro bodybuilding career. Even though he would earn his pro card in 2012 at the North Americans, he would not make his pro debut until 2015 where he won his pro debut the 2015 California pro at the age of 24 years old. So because Dallas was such a well-known bodybuilder, I don't think people really realized how short his pro career was and how much raw potential this guy had. Because his pro career started in 2015 and ended with his death in 2017 just two years later. Now in 2015, he would also make his Olympia debut placing 13th at his first Olympia ever. And he would make tremendous improvements going into the 2016 Mr. Olympia where he would place 8th. So top 10 finished at his second Olympia ever. 8th place, very good placing for Dallas McCarver. And that same year in 2016, he would also win the Chicago Pro aka the wings of strength and he would place 9th at the Arnold Classic Europe. Now 2017, which was Dallas McCarver's last year as a pro bodybuilder, was arguably his biggest and best year as a pro bodybuilder. The second place finished in March of 2017 at the Arnold Classic Ohio, the second biggest show in bodybuilding. And not only that, Dallas McCarver had peaked out his physique in the offseason to pushing 350 pounds, his biggest and best physique ever. And that's when we would first start to see signs that something was wrong. Following the Arnold Classic Ohio, of course there's the Arnold Classic Australia. Dallas McCarver slated to compete there. Arguably could have won the Arnold Australia. Had nothing gone wrong. As we know, at that show, Dallas McCarver collapsed on stage and he was not able to finish that show. And from that point forward, we would not see Dallas McCarver compete again. So that second place finished at the Arnold Ohio would be his final placing as a pro bodybuilder before passing away in September of 2017 at the age of 26 years old. Making him to my knowledge the youngest pro bodybuilder to pass away. So I just wanted to make a video kind of remembering Dallas for the things that he did achieve in such a very short time. Three competitive seasons as a pro bodybuilder 2015, 2016 and 2017. During that time, winning two pro shows, including his pro debut, placing top 10 at the Mr. Olympia and becoming runner up at the Arnold Classic in Columbus, Ohio, the second big show in bodybuilding. On top of that being one of the youngest bodybuilders ever to turn pro, one of the very few bodybuilders that has been able to turn pro on their third ever show, which is a feat that I don't know for ever going to see again. I mean, that's a very impressive just just a perfect example of someone that just had what it took to be a pro bodybuilder turning pro on their third show. I mean, I can't say enough how impressive that really is. So I hope you guys enjoyed the video. Please give it a thumbs up, give it a like, help keep Dallas as legacy alive. And hopefully he will be remembered for the great things that he actually did in bodybuilding. And not so much the focus that the mainstream media has to say about him. So thank you guys for watching the video. Next time, a power signing out.

Classic physique is really trying to figure out what exactly they're looking for in terms of what physique they're going to be rewarding at the Olympia. Danny Hester being the first Mr. Olympia ever in classic and then Brianna being the second in 2017. This is the same thing that we saw with women's physique. Women's figure as those divisions were new, it started to come into their own. The look that they were actually looking for started to become more and more apparent as we saw the people that were winning and getting rewarded for how they looked. So I think that's the great thing about classic physique is because with these weight and height restrictions, it gives you a very wide range of different physique. You've got taller guys with bigger wider structures and you've got shorter, very aesthetic guys that are very dense and muscular. A whole wide spectrum of different kinds of physique to choose from in classic physique. And I think that's what makes it so interesting in contrast to men's open where everybody is just big and they have slightly different variations in their physique. Classic physique with all these different heights and weights, you have a lot of completely different looks in that division. But I think the type of physique that they're looking for is starting to change a little bit and they're starting to decide they want a little bit of a bigger physique, a wider physique, a bigger frame, a bigger structure. You could say something more like an Arnold Schwarzenegger or something more like a surge new bra or something more like a Sergio Aleva. Just a bigger, more imposing physique on stage seems to be the trend of what's getting rewarded recently. So when people refer to a Corvette, you're going to hear them refer to it as being a C1, C2, C3, C4, or C7. So the new Corvette that I got is a C7 and the Corvette you see next to it is a C3. So for those of you that don't know, the Corvette Stingray was first introduced in 1963 as a C2 Corvette. And it would span all the way until 1976 spanning both the C2 and C3 generations of Corvette. So from C4 onward, there would not be another Corvette Stingray until the C7 introduced in 2014. So this is a kind of a big deal in Corvette history. Almost 40 years they did not have a stingray and they came back with it in 2014. So as much as I like bodybuilding history, I think car history is just as cool. === FILE: First World's Strongest Man 1977： Bodybuilders vs Football Players vs Wrestlers [OQ-Tad_GGeQ].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's Name of Power. So today I want to make a video about the very first ever world strongest man competition. So the first ever world strongest man was held in 1977 and back at that time there was no you know strong man competitor. There wasn't like an amateur league, a pro league, something feeding into the world strongest man competition where you had to qualify as a strong man. As a strong man competitor. So basically what they did back in 1977 was they took who they believed to be the strongest man in the world just from various different sports. You had body builders, you had professional wrestlers, you had Olympic weight lifters, you had football players, just kind of a hard podge of guys that were believed to be super strong. So I think if you guys find body building history to be interesting, you guys would find world strongest man history to be even more interesting because of the humble roots that it really had. The kind of the interesting, you know, the interesting aspects of who they picked to be in this first strong man competition. You have Franco Columbo who at that time had won the Mr. Olympia the year prior. And during that 1977 world strongest man he would suffer a pretty big injury that would almost end his career in doing his leg during this carry where he was carrying a fridge on his back. That would basically be the reason why a lot of people think when he came back in 1981 that his physique was so off specifically his legs and he had a little bit of guy know in 1981. And some people think he may have continued to compete in Winna Olympia's had he not done that world strongest man in 1977. Of course you had the legendary Lou Fragno at that time I believe 1977 was about the year that he got his incredible Hawk deal and he started filming the incredible Hawk for TV. He may have even been noticed on the world strongest man that might have been where that came about. At that time obviously he was known for pumping iron which it came out a couple years prior. And he's also a two-time IFBB mystery universe and the IFBB mystery America. You had Kent Petera who was a pro wrestler. He was also a very accomplished weightlifter in my opinion one of the pound for pound strongest pro wrestlers of all time. To have come from such an accomplished weightlifting background he was also in it. Yet Bob Young who was a football player. I believe at that time he was playing for the St. Louis Cardinals as an offensive guard. You had another body builder in there by the name of Mike Dayton who might also make an interesting video. This guy was a classic body builder from back in the Golden Era. He was actually an IFBB mystery America. And he actually had a pretty incredible physique for that era. And then of course you had George Friend who was a hammer thrower. You had John Cole who was an AAU weightlifter. Then of course you had the winner Bruce Willham. So Bruce Willham was a Olympic weightlifting champion. And obviously the first ever world strongest man. He's actually a two-time world strongest man who had returned to win again in 1978. And this guy was a pretty massive dude. This guy was six foot two, 320 pounds or 150 kilograms. So this guy was a big guy. So not only was this lineup kind of a hodgepodge of people believed to be the best that they're given sports and the strongest that they're given sports. They really had no way of knowing what they were getting into and really had no way of training or preparing specifically for the world strongest man like we see today. The guys that compete today are strong man competitors. They know what the lifts are going to be. They know what you know. All the events are going to be and they can train for all those things at their gym leading up to the world strongest man competition. So they at least know what they're getting into. Where's these guys? It was kind of show up. See how much you can lift. See what you can do. So there were eight men in total and there were ten events in total. There was one event called the barrel lift where you basically just saw who could lift the heaviest barrel. There wasn't event called the bar bend where they basically just bent a steel rod in half. And the way they judged that was the bars got increasingly thicker as they went. So ever could bend the thickest bar was the winner of that. There's the third event called the wrist roll where they basically just lifted a hundred pounds up with a rope. Kind of an odd event. Mike Dayton won that event. You had an event called the tire toss, which as the name suggests they were tossing tires for distance. You had something called the tram pull, which is something you still see today where they're pulling an 8,000 pound vehicle. I guess that was for time. They all had to pull it 40 yards and ever pulled it the quickest was the winner. Yeah, the car deadlift, which is something that you still see today as well. I believe they did that for reps. Whoever had the most reps was the winner. And then probably one of the most interesting of all these events was an event called the girl squat. So the girl squat was kind of fascinating. They had to squat girls in a cage. So yes, they literally had girls in a cage and the men had to squat them for reps. So that's probably something you'll never see on the world's strongest man stage ever again. And then of course we have the infamous refrigerator race where you strap a 410 pound refrigerator to your back. Then you run with it. And that is actually where Franco Columbo got injured was doing that about 10 yards in. But despite that injury, Franco Columbo still managed to place fifth out of eight men at the 1977 World Strongest Man. Then of course you also had the good old tug of war. What's a better way of judging strength and an old fashioned tug of war. So that was in there. And after all these events were said and done, you had Bruce Willham and first, yeah Bob Young and second Ken Petera and third, Lou Frigno taking fourth beating his fellow body, Boat of Franco Columbo, yeah Franco Columbo and fifth obviously John Colton sixth, Mike Dayton and seventh and George friend the hammer thrower in eighth place. Now another interesting little fact about this first world strongest man is that seven of the eight competitors from the United States, only one Franco Columbo was from Italy. So obviously today we see all the competitors are from all over the world. Typically a lot of these guys are winning from other countries at the United States, but definitely in 1977 it was certainly stacked in the favor of the United States for the winner of the World Strongest Man to be an American. So this sport of strong man has certainly come a long way in the four decades that it's been around since 1977 and they've really refined things in terms of the competitions, the events, the way that they train and prepare for these events. I think the fact that there's a strong man organization where they can be pro and compete leading up to the world strongest man to qualify. And really as a practice for the World Strongest Man, I'm really makes it much better than 1977 just picking a bunch of random guys that were big. Let's see how much you can lift and then we'll name the strongest guy of World Strongest Man. It's a much more organized, much more refined way of doing it today. But I thought you guys might enjoy that video a little bit of history for you guys on Strong Man. Thank you guys for watching the video. Please go to a thumbs up if you did enjoy it. === FILE: Forgotten Bodybuilder： Eddie Robinson [fs1s0XIZsmw].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's Render Power, so I'm gonna make a video about a forgotten body builder by the name of Eddie Robinson. Now, Eddie Robinson was a bodybuilder who's career span in the 1980s and the 1990s, competing primarily in the IFBB, but that's what we're gonna talk about later on in this video. To leave the IFBB in 1991 to join Vince McMahon's WBF or the World Bodybuilding Federation, placing fourth in 1991 at the WBF Championships, and then placing sixth at the 1992 WBF Championships. So as we know history goes to show that the WBF was not successful and they just banded in 1992, however, a lot of those bodybuilders that went over to the WBF, they still wanted to compete and they wanted to come back to the IFBB. Now, for anyone that says politics don't play any role in bodybuilding, the WBF is a perfect example of when politics came into play, is that most of these bodybuilders that were great top level bodybuilders in the IFBB prior to leaving for the WBF, when they would return to the IFBB, their careers would be nothing like they were before. And I think Eddie Robinson is a perfect example of that and that's why he's one of my forgotten bodybuilders on my forgotten bodybuilder list, is because he's really someone you don't hear people talk about as one of these great kind of classic guys, one of these great 90s guys. He's not really in the conversation with the little drones, the flex wheelers, the mic front swaths, even like the Marcus Rules, a lot of these guys from the 90s, granted flex will learn Kevin LeVrony, who run her up at the Mr. Olympia, but Eddie Robinson was still an amazing bodybuilder to come out of that era and you really don't hear a lot of people talking about him. So let's talk a little bit about Eddie Robinson's career prior to the WBF. So he would turn pro by winning the Mr. USA in 1989. And he actually had a really impressive pro debut or pro year in 1990, winning the Niagara Falls pro his first IFB show ever, placing sixth at the night of champions at that time, arguably, the second or third biggest show at that time, the Arnold Classic started in 1989. But prior to that, the night of champions was pretty much the second biggest title. So the Arnold was still relatively new back then. So he's a top six guy at one of the biggest shows right off the bat. And then at the Mr. Olympia competition, that same year he placed tenth. So top ten at the Mr. Olympia his first time ever. Again, this is something that's very hard to do as a rookie. So 1991 comes along his second year as a pro bodybuilder. Invincible man is throwing around money. That's way more than anything these bodybuilders were making over in the IFB from winning shows. Invincible man was doing it differently. He would pay you a contract just to come over and compete. You didn't even have to win the show. He would give you money just to be in the WBF. So you got to think, here's a young bodybuilder. Just turned pro in the IFBB. Didn't really make much if any money at all from the shows that he won or placed highly at. And here's Vince McMahon talking about probably hundreds of thousands of dollars that Eddie Robinson, who was a top four guy to show. Just to come compete. So I mean, it's an easy decision if you're Eddie Robinson in 1991. Let's go with the big money because this obviously looked like something that was big and promising. This Vince McMahon, I mean the WBF was huge at the time. This was the attitude era of wrestling. So I mean of course, that's a very tempting offer. And I'm sure a lot of these guys never anticipated that this Federation would fail after just two years and two championships being held. So after 1992, Eddie Robinson takes about a three-year hiatus from pro bodybuilding. And he tries to return to the IFB in 1995. So from 1995 to 1999, those next four years Eddie Robinson will be trying again to do well in the IFB. And we would actually never see him on the Olympia stage again throughout his IFB professional career during his comeback. So 1995, he did do relatively well. He placed top 10 at the Knight of Champions, placing eighth. But then some of those smaller shows would come along in 1995. Those grand prees, placing outside of the top six at both of those that year, the grand pre-franc and the grand pre-you crane, placing eighth at both of those shows. And then from that point forward, his best placing would be at this Florida pro-invitational in 1996 where he would place fourth. But outside of that, you would see him mostly placing outside of the top six. So this was a guy who went from his rookie year, placing top 10 at the Olympia winning the Niagara show to never winning a pro show in the IFB again. And really never placing top six again at any really major show. And of course the obvious never grazing the Olympia stage again. And that's why I want to make a video about this guy because although he never really placed highly during his comeback years with the IFB and I think that's the big reason why he became kind of a forgotten bodybuilder. Eddie had a really incredible physique for the 1990s. I mean this guy had the size, he had the mass, I mean that crazy, you know, granite like density to his physique that you just don't see too often. And he was just extremely complete. I mean his arms looked amazing, his legs looked amazing. Crazy mass throughout the upper body. It was just something we didn't really get the chance to see on the Olympia stage on the IFB ever again. But the fact of the matter is this guy was impressive and this guy had it all. But for the most part, I think this guy's just an incredible bodybuilder, left the IFB and they weren't too happy about that. So it seems like the more forgotten bodybuilder videos that I do from bodybuilders from the 70s, the more bodybuilders that seem to come up, that have these very long careers in bodybuilding spanning four or five decades even. And Peter Selich is one of those. Beginning his competitive career in 1975 and competing all the way up until 2012, where he was in the 60 plus category at the age of 62. Specifically, he didn't have much of a career in the IFBB. And typically the most well known golden era bodybuilders are either going to be from the IFBB or possibly even NABBA. Now even though Peter Selich didn't primarily compete in either of those federations, he still had a very impressive physique for the golden era. Specifically his conditioning and vascularity was arguably one of the best from the golden era. Again, the golden era guys are all great. They were smaller guys than they were today. But the conditioning, there were very few guys that really had that crazy shredded lean conditioning and that crazy vascularity. And I believe Peter Selich was one of them. Even though again he was a smaller guy. He didn't have as much muscle mass as a guy like Arnold Schwarzenegger. But his conditioning was certainly one of the best of that era. Fast forward to 2003 almost 10 years later he'd win the WFF World Championships in the WF European Championships in 2004, IVF A World Championships. And then he would win the IFBB World Championships in 2011 and 2012, 2012 being the better of the two years, winning both the Masters 50 plus category and the Master 60 plus category at the 2012 IFBB World Championships. So Peter Selich's competition weight in his younger years was about 213 pounds on stage or 97 kilograms with 19 inch arms or 48 centimeters and only a 34 inch waist or 86 centimeters. He has currently 68 years old and a couple other interesting facts about him. He actually became the IFBB president for Yugoslavia in 1977 and he has most known for winning a total of 10 World Championships over the course of his five decades spanning bodybuilding career. I think this is one of the most fascinating rivalries in bodybuilding history because it's a clear example of size versus conditioning. In the fact that Arnold was nearly 40 to 50 pounds heavier than Frank Zayn on stage, but there was still an occasion where Frank Zayn would defeat Arnold Schwarzenegger. So one of the points I wanted to get to in this video is when a lot of people think of Arnold's famous rivalries, they tend to think of Arnold versus Sergio Oliva, or maybe even Arnold versus Lou Frigno as seen in Pumping Iron. But the interesting thing here is Arnold versus Frank Zayn actually predates his rivalry with both Lou Frigno and Sergio Oliva and also post dates. The rivalry of Sergio and the rivalry with Lou. So Frank Zayn's bodybuilding career actually goes a little bit further back than Arnold Schwarzenegger's. Frank Zayn was competing starting in 1961 with his first show ever being the Mr. Pennsylvania competition. And Arnold Schwarzenegger was starting competing about 40 years later in 1965. Now throughout the 60s, Frank Zayn was able to obtain a title that Arnold Schwarzenegger was never able to obtain and that would be the Mr. America title. So Frank Zayn would win that title three times in the 1960s, specifically the IFB Mr. America and not the AAU Mr. America. He would win that in 1966, 1967 and again in 1968. So the year 1968 would bring us to the year that the rivalry between Frank Zayn and Arnold Schwarzenegger started. Now again, Arnold would not appear at his first Mr. Olympia competition until 1969. So this actually predates any of Arnold's Olympia wins and any of his Olympia rivalries which would include Lou Frigno and Sergio Oliva. Now at this point in time, Arnold had only been beaten once on a bodybuilding stage. Now history will show that Arnold has only been beaten three times total on a bodybuilding stage. Now the 1968 IFB Mr. Universe would be one of those times. So in 1968 Arnold and Frank Zayn would go head to head. Arnold was much bigger than Frank Zayn, much fuller, much rounder. And again, just much bigger overall. But Frank Zayn was so much more conditioned than Arnold that despite being much smaller than him, he defeated Arnold and Arnold was expecting obviously to win this Mr. Universe. So this really sent Arnold back to the drawing board and it put Frank Zayn on the map for beating this guy that was significantly bigger than him and it really started the trend and set the bar higher for guys like Arnold. Okay, if we're going to win shows, we've got to have better conditioning. Clearly conditioning is something they're looking for. This Frank Zayn guy is beating guys that are significantly bigger than him because it's conditioning is so crazy. So it really set the bar higher for Arnold and then when he would make his first Olympia appearance in 69 and then into the 1970s, he would have much better conditioning than the conditioning that you would see from him throughout the 60s. So in my opinion, losing to Frank Zayn actually made Arnold a much better bodybuilder because after that defeat, he actually really never saw Arnold come in with conditioning that was off from that point forward. He had actually looked pretty well conditioned at every Olympia appearance he would make. And of course the following year Arnold would finally nap that IFB Mr. Universe win in New York in 1969 and that same year he would also win the NABA Mr. Universe over in London. And then in 1969 Arnold will compete in his first Olympia taking second to Sergio Oliva then in 1970 that would be the beginning of the reign of Arnold Schwarzenegger which would last six years then of course he would come back in 1980 which I'm going to talk about in a minute because that's where the rivalry between him and Frank Zayn culminated was at that 1980 Mr. Olympia. So as I mentioned before Arnold would start competing in the Olympia in 1969 and he would compete through 1975. And Frank Zayn would begin competing at the Olympia in 1972. So despite the fact they were competing at the Olympia at the same time, the really fascinating thing here is that the two of them would actually never go head to head on the Olympia stage during that entire time from 70 to 75 where Arnold was competing because at this point in 1972 when Frank Zayn finally came over to the Olympia, they had implemented the over 200 and under 200 categories at the Olympia. So what this meant was everybody under 200 pounds of compete and then there would be a winner of that division. Everybody over 200 pounds of compete. There'd be a winner of that division and the winners of the both divisions, the over and under they would go head to head for the overall Mr. Olympia title. So from 1972 to 1976 Frank Zayn actually never won the over 200 division so he never had the opportunity to go head to head with one of the over 200 guys like Arnold. So even though they competed the same years, they didn't compete against each other those same years. So Arnold would retire in 1975 and then Frank Zayn would go on to play second at the 1976 Mr. Olympia in the under 200. Then from 1977 to 1979 he would win both the under 200 and the overall Mr. Olympia titles for three years in a row going into the 1980 Mr. Olympia. Arnold Schwarzenegger beat Chris Dickerson.
