=== FILE: Golden Era VS Modern Bodybuilding [flc-L_XzYEo].txt ===

What's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the power zone. This video I wanted to compare the golden era of bodybuilding with the modern era of bodybuilding. Now of course there's a lot of things that I prefer about the golden era of bodybuilding to today's bodybuilding but there's actually a lot of things today that they are doing better and they did back in the 60s and 70s. Typically I think the changes made to the Mr. Olympia competition over the years specifically how you qualify for the Mr. Olympia is one of the biggest changes between the golden era of bodybuilding and the modern era of bodybuilding. I think it was actually a change that happened for the better. So in the early days of bodybuilding and in the early days of the Mr. Olympia competition Joe Weeder actually initially created the Mr. Olympia as a place for Mr. Universe competitors or Mr. Universe winners to compete and win money. So in the early days the only way to qualify for the Mr. Olympia was to be a winner of the Mr. Universe. So in many cases in the 60s and even the 70s there were Mr. Olympia competitions with three two or even only one competitor where the only person that showed up was the one that won at the Olympia. So a lot of those early years you could count the number of competitors on one hand and in some cases on one finger and that's one of the things that has changed dramatically over the years up until today's Mr. Olympia which I think is for the better in some cases you see you know 25 to 30 guys on the Olympia stage today there's much more ways to qualify and because of that I think the Mr. Olympia is much more interesting today and much more competitive today than it was back in you know the 60s and 70s. So to give you guys a little perspective on that in Arnold Schwarzenegger's first six Mr. Olympia wins from 1970 to 1975 when he would retire from bodybuilding he would only beat a total of seven different competitors to win those six titles. So some of the more recent years at the Mr. Olympia and one year there's three to four times that many competitors at the Mr. Olympia. So over a span of six years Arnold only had to be seven guys where's a guy like a Phil Heath or Ronnie Coleman might have to be 20 or 25, 26 just to win one show. Now of course that would change as time went on and Arnold came back in 1980 to win the Mr. Olympia and in that competition there were 16 competitors bringing Arnold's total to 20 total different competitors that he beat over the years. Now I'd say the main reason for this change number one more bodybuilders overall interested in bodybuilding and competing in bodybuilding thus more pro bodybuilders but also the way that you qualify for the Mr. Olympia today. So of course you automatically have the top five from the previous years of Olympia qualifying for the next years of Olympia then of course you also have the winner of each contest. So if you win a pro show you qualify for the Mr. Olympia and as we all know there's quite a few pro shows out there. So winning a pro show constitutes the vast majority of the people that you're going to see in the Mr. Olympia lineup today then you also have the opportunity for a select few guys the top three in the point standing so if you can compete a lot during the course of the year and whatever show it is really as long as you're placing and earning points with those placing you could technically qualify for the Olympia on points. So modern bodybuilding is not all bad. Of course I am a fan of the golden era and a lot of people look back to the golden era as the best time in bodybuilding but I think having the Mr. Olympia going from you got to win the Mr. Universe to compete at the Mr. Olympia. Having all these different opportunities for bodybuilders different paths for them to get to the Mr. Olympia. I think it's a much better way leads to a much more competitive lineup and overall is better for the Olympia in general. And then of course another major change from the golden era bodybuilding to today would be the fact that there's no rival organization to the IAPB really today. There's nothing really on the same level or even close to being the same level as the IAPB today. Whereas back in the day you had NAVA you had the AAU you had multiple other venues for professional bodybuilders to compete that weren't the IAPB and you don't have that today. So the IAPB is kind of a bodybuilding monopoly so to speak today. I don't know if that's for the better or for the worse that is one major change between the golden era and today. And of course back then you had the Mr. America titles and the Mr. USA titles. Both of those were under a different organization than the IAPB. Whereas today the Mr. America has became NPC Nationals and the Mr. USA has become the USA the NPC USA's. And as we know the NPC is the organization that basically feeds into the IAPB. So both of those competitions the Mr. America and the Mr. USA are gone and now fall under the banner of the NPC with the USA's and the Nationals. And then of course we have the main comparison that people like to talk about and that is the caliber of competitor from the 1970s the golden era bodybuilding versus the caliber of competitor today. And I'll say the primary difference between these two types of physics is going to be number one the type and amount of drugs that is used in bodybuilding because back then they did not have growth hormone they did not have peptides really they did not have insulin they basically had the basics and today you know obviously you know sports enhancement technology has you know vastly improved and evolved to the point where these guys have these crazy stacks and these guys are taking all kinds of stuff and back then it was really really simple and the knowledge of nutrition back then also was very very simple. Especially compared to the point that nutrition has gotten to today and as a result of this the main difference that we're seeing in the physics of the guys today and the guys in the golden era are that the physics today are simply bigger and whether that's a good thing or a bad thing I'll let you guys decide that a lot of the physics today are very impressive physics very muscular physics very heavy physics very thick very dense just a lot of size there and back in the day there's a lot more emphasis on lines structure aesthetics and posing and size wasn't necessarily that big of a factor of course they want to they want you to be one of the most muscular guys on stage if you're going to win one of these competitions whether it was back then or today but back then you did have a guy like Frank Zane winning three-mister Olympias against guys that were bigger than him you did have the over 200 and under 200 division at the Mr Olympia back in the and one of the things that I think was good about that separation is the guy that won the over 200 and the guy that won the under 200 would then go head to head for the Mr Olympia title and so they would win their technically weight air did but again bodybuilding is very subjective it's all opinion based so whether you prefer the golden era of bodybuilding the physique back then or the physique's now nobody's really right or wrong I mean both physique's you could make an argument that either one is better because again it's very subjective and it's very opinion based and everybody has their own opinion on what they like in bodybuilding and that brings me to the final and what I think is probably the most important difference between the golden era of bodybuilding and the modern era of bodybuilding and that is social media back in the golden era fans really didn't have that much opportunity to interact with their favorite bodybuilders they had to write them letters or send them fan mail the accessibility just wasn't there and I think as a result bodybuilding remained a very niche sport for a very long time it's only a select group of you know hardcore fans that really followed bodybuilding and went to bodybuilding shows and went to whatever meet and greet there might have been and bodybuilding stayed very limited because it wasn't really so much in the mainstream eye and I personally think social media today is the reason why body building has blown up to the point that it has there can be channels like mine or a Louis Marko or an RX muscle channels that cover bodybuilding and this is the reason why I think the magazine's died and that's a major difference between you know the golden era and now is these guys in the golden era we're banking on getting a magazine contract or being on the cover of a magazine or being featured in a magazine advertising a product where as today the landscape has completely shifted and these guys the focus of being a bodybuilder is how can you best market yourself on instagram on twitter on facebook on youtube how can you get the most followers and get a supplement company dispenser you based on how many followers you have and again you can make an argument for whether or not that's good or whether not that's bad but I think overall social media has been good for body building it's provided a lot of opportunity to reach new fans and to reach the mainstream I think channels like mine and bodybuilding channels in general that cover bodybuilding are great for bodybuilding I get comments all the time on this channel saying hey you know I had no interest in bodybuilding before I saw one of your videos I click subscribe and ever since I've been watching you know all the coverage that you do on bodybuilding competitions and I developed a fascination with the sport of bodybuilding now I watch every single show and I know the winners of you know the new York pro or the Toronto pro or any given small show whereas before your channel I didn't even know what the Mr. Olympia was so I think social media now has brought bodybuilding to an entirely new audience because a lot of new people can be exposed to it via social media and I think that's great for the sport more fans is more revenue and I think that's going to lead to a better IFB be a better Mr. Olympia as a show and a better quality of competitor in the long run. So let me know what you guys think in the comment section below which do you think was a better time for bodybuilding in general and I'm not just talking about the quality of the physique I'm talking about the organizations the competitions and the level of competition in general so let me know in the comment section below please give this video a thumbs up if you enjoyed it next time of a power signing out

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the Power. So a week ago I published a video titled The Strongest High Schoolers of 2018. I made that video based on essentially a survey done by the USA Weightlifting Organization. They surveyed all these schools and they had these schools submit videos of their strongest students during the bench press, the squat, and a power clean. They tell it up those results and came up with a top 10 list for the males and the females of each school. And then they published those lists as the strongest high schoolers of 2018. So after I posted this video I had several people commenting, I'm in high school and I can bench press 500 pounds, 600 pounds, all these unsubstantiated claims. So I came up with the idea of owner to find the strongest high school lift ever, and each of the respective lifts. So in this video we're going to talk about the strongest high school bench press. And in particular the strongest high school bench press that I could find. So the best bench press that I could find performed by a high schooler. We have to go back to 2013 for that. So Matt Porsal-Tani, 18 years old in 2013, standing 5 foot 11 and weighing roughly 271 pounds. Bench pressed 700 pounds while wearing a bench shirt. So it wasn't a raw lift, but keep in mind we're talking about a 700 pound bench press by a high schooler. Now even more impressive possibly was the year before that he set the record at 570 pounds at the age of 17 years old. So he broke his own record, improving his bench press by 130 pounds in just one year's time. And unlike some of the power lifters mentioned in the strongest high schooler of 2018 video, we actually do have video events of this lift being performed. And it was done in a sanctioned meat. It was judged. It was witnessed. It was recorded. This is an official high schooler bench pressing 700 pounds. Now to put that in perspective back in 2013, the bench press world record for the raw bench press was only 722 pounds. And the biggest bench press ever with a bench press shirt was set by Ryan Kennedy in 2008. And that was a 175 pound bench press. But both of these guys that set these bench press records were guys with decades more lifting experience than this high schooler. And almost 100 pounds in some cases more than 100 pounds heavier than him. Most of them weigh in close to 400 pounds if not over 400 pounds. This kid weighing 271 pounds. With only a couple of years of lifting experience under his belt. Making this one of the most impressive high school feats of strength that I've ever seen. But I think that small waist is a very serious factor in determining whether or not he's going to be able to win the Mr. Olympia. There's just a certain degree of density, size, and detail, missing from Rolie winkler's upper back, and his lower lads really almost seem non-existent. So when you put Rolie up against a top Olympia guy, say, Phil Heath, who is, you know, basically one of the masters of the back double bicep, it's going to prevent Rolie from really winning or beating Phil Heath because he can't really win those back poses against Phil, even if Phil came in completely off, I think Rolie would have a very hard time beating Phil, just because I think nine times out of ten, he's going to lose those back shots to Phil. So first we look at Rich Piano's weight as a body builder. He could have been a little bit more conditioned but overall at 270 pounds a pretty impressive body builder especially for someone in the amateur ranks. So a pretty impressive deadlift by Rich Piano. And the final lift given on this list I'm a little bit skeptical of this because I know how hard it is to do a heavy curl. He claims to have 275 pounds barbell curl or 125 kilograms for three reps. So almost a 300 pound curl for three reps. I don't know how realistic that number is but that is the number that Rich Piano gave in this interview. Now the other lifts I think they're very feasible and probably something that was very possible for somebody of Rich Piano's size. And I'll be also with you guys. I'm actually pretty impressed with the 585 pound deadlift by Rich Piano. Now it is worth mentioning in this video that towards the end of his career there was a little bit of controversy with people claiming that Rich Piano would bring fake weights to the gym specifically for filming purposes to make his YouTube videos look a little bit more impressive and look a little bit more intense. Now whether or not that is actually true I'm still inclined to believe most of these numbers that he gave out because he did say in that interview these were numbers that he achieved at his prime of his strength. So probably the version of Rich Piano that we saw on YouTube was an aging version of Rich Piano. It probably wasn't Rich Piano at the prime of his strength. And as we saw from those videos he was a big fan of using the cables. === FILE: Is Bodybuilding Dying？ [rrM6Fyojm2U].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the power so the question of the day is, is body building dying? So I've seen this question over and over again and I've seen this comment over and over again that body building is a dying industry body building as a sport as a pageant whatever you want to call it is dying There's even some body building YouTubers that are now switching away from making body building videos because they also claim that body building is dying So the question is body building dying is kind of a loaded question so to answer this question is body building in terms of general interest in the sport is interest in body building starting to die and the answer to that question is absolutely not Interested body building I think has actually never been higher than it is right now is the quality of the competitor starting to die. I think the answer to that question might be yes I think social media has brought more attention and more interest to body building than ever before in the history of the sport I think body building right now is really at an all-time high of interest. Do you have body builders like fill Heath, J. Cutler and Kai Green with millions? Millions of followers on social media So I say that body building is that it's all time most popular state because someone like Kai Green can have millions of followers without even having one the biggest body building show Ever the Mr. Olympia back in the 70s amongst body building fans body building was very popular Arnold Schwarzenegger was a hero the body building fans But I wouldn't say back in the 70s Lou Ferigno Arnold Schwarzenegger Serge new brai Frank Zane. I wouldn't say these guys were known by millions of people I wouldn't say these guys were followed by millions of people. I would say within the kind of cult like body building community They were very heavily followed but it wasn't a worldwide phenomenon like it is today even back when I started working out when I was like 14 or 15 going to the gym back in 2008 2009 This was prior to Instagram prior to you know Twitter prior to most social media before YouTube really took off There wasn't a whole lot of body building content out there really the only thing out there was my space a couple top body builders like Jay Cutler I think he had a mice base back in the day and I followed him on my space but back then there wasn't a whole lot of interest in going to the gym amongst teenagers and kids because there wasn't an Instagram I think Instagram right now and these body builders being on Instagram is a big reason for why going to the gym taking supplements following body building is so popular because they see it on Instagram But back in like 2007 2008 2009 when I first started working out and there was none of that I was like the only person my age going to the gym. Absolutely not I think the interest is just growing and continually growing. I think the fan base is also growing and continually growing and body building Through that is gonna get bigger there's gonna be more people buying supplements more people buying tickets more people body building And I have 200 million views on my channel 400 thousand subscribers on my channel and this is just commentary on body building So for people to say body building is dying There's a lack of interest in body building people are starting to leave the sport as fans I think there's absolutely zero truth to that whatsoever However, if you look at the other standpoint of the question is body building dying And you look at the caliber of the competitor the level of competition the types of people that are winning pro shows The types of physique that are being rewarded at pro shows Then the question is a little bit different the answer to that question could absolutely be yes because at these shows They're seeing guys place very highly with very very poor conditioning You're seeing guys being rewarded for coming in big and full and around But they also have a massive stomach and a massive gut to go with that fullness and roundness But it seems that the judges are looking for okay, you're big and full and round It doesn't matter if the midsection isn't there So I think in that regard the answer to the question is yes that attitude towards body building the bigger is better We want the most muscular guy Get his biggest possible and we're going to reward you coming full coming freaky coming massive that attitude I think is killing the sport of body building 100% And not just from a theoretical standpoint literally killing the sport of body building I mean look what happened Dallas Macarver Dallas Macarver's a young kid Obviously the sport of body building to him was about getting as big as possible I believe at one point he weighed 350 pounds in the off season If not even more than that his goal was clearly just to get massive to get big And the judges were rewarding him as shows second place at the Arnold Classic top 10 at the Mr. Olympia So clearly they were looking for a look like that And because of that Dallas kept pushing himself and he ended up dead the sport of body building Not only dying but literally killing the people participating in it However, there does seem to be an antidote to this problem and that antidote seems to be classic physique Classic physique was the answer of the IAPB to this problem specifically They wanted to draw more mainstream interest into the sport They wanted to present a healthier kind of safer, more downsized physique That was kind of a reminiscent of the 70s the golden Arab body building classic physique What some hardcore body building fans consider to be a real body building They don't really want the mass monster they don't really want the freak There's a lot of hardcore body building fans that want the aesthetic physique the old school physique Kind of a respectable well-posed well presented physique And classic physique was the answer to that problem So it's not like there was this issue of big guts, bad conditioning and mass monsters And no one was doing anything about it that wasn't the case it was actually a case of the IAPB in my opinion Actually did a really good job of recognizing this a lot of people were complaining about it a lot of people were complaining and criticizing About the bubble guts about the size and condition of these guys and saying hey, you know, this is not body building This is not what we want to see and the IAPB clearly saw those comments They clearly saw that attitude in that opinion and that was why they answered with classic physique So the question is body building dying I think the term body building in that question refers to all categories classic physique men's physique body building Two 12 body building men's open body building any of these divisions where someone is competing and showing their physique they build up over think that's all going to change. === FILE: Is Classic Physique Easier than Bodybuilding？ [mrRACSC_38U].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the power. So today I want to talk about the topic of classic physique being easier than body building. Now this topic has come about from both the Phil Heath interview where he's talking about. Classic physique guys are just guys that aren't cut out to be Mr. Olympia calling them weakened warrior stuff like that. But recently I saw other body builders chiming in on this other pro body builders. I'm that seem to agree a little bit with what Phil Heath was saying. And one of the videos in particular that I saw I just saw today actually. They drew the comparison that when everyone watched cartoons as kids, they wanted to be the incredible hawk. They wanted to be he-man. They didn't want to be spider-man or aquaman, the more downsized, but more aesthetic physique. So the argument that lies within that is that everyone wants to be the bigger guy but some people can't. So that's why they go to classic physique. Now honestly I do think there's a lot of truth in that. And that could be why classic physique is growing so fast. It's because a lot of guys realize, you know, they can't be that big. But in addition to that, I think the reality of the situation is the mentality is changing. I don't think it's just guys looking for an easier route. I think it's guys looking for a better route. Guys looking for a healthier route. Guys looking for a more attainable and really a more realistic route. So while I do feel like there is the potential that there's probably some guys. Potentially a lot of guys that pick classic physique because it's an easier division. They have more pro cards. It's just an easier way for them to become pro. The categories, the heightened weight, makes it easier for you to fit into that division. I understand that and I do understand the mentality behind men's open body builders thinking, well these guys are looking for an easier way to be body builders. They want to be body builders, but they can't be. And I don't think that's necessarily true. I honestly think that now the mentality starting to change because of the things that we've seen recently with rich Piana Dallas Macarver. Guys don't want to be the mass monster anymore. They don't look up to the mass monster anymore. They're still impressed by, okay, this guy's huge. Look how much muscle this guy has. But I think the days of, okay, I want to be this 400 pound monster. I think those days are starting to end. And people are looking back to the golden Arab body building and calling it the golden Arab body building. Because those are the physiques that they would really like to have. Because I firmly believe that classic physique is body building. It's the same thing. It's classic body building. Back in the 70s. Some of these guys that you see in the classic physique Olympia today, if they competed in the 70s, they'd be considered big guys back in the 70s. They'd be considered, you know, the top body builders back in the 70s. So just because body building today has evolved into what it has evolved into, doesn't mean that's what body building always has been. So I feel like the mentality is changing and people are looking back to the 70s. Like this, you know, I prefer this version of body building over today's version of body building. I mean, both of these are body building. So while it may offer some people equal to equal to equal to easier route, I think a lot of people are getting into it because they like that look. I think that's really the genuine truth to it. Is it prefer that older classic look, a more downsized look, not so much a, you know, mass monster look. They really want to look like that. That's really what they see themselves looking like. They don't want to, I mean, call me crazy, but they don't want to look like a fill-heat. They don't want to look like a big Romney. It's fun to watch a guy like fill-heat. If a guy like big Romney, a guy like Dennis Wolf, it's fun to watch these giant guys on stage. There's no doubt about it, but not everyone wants to look like that guy. And I think more and more the mentality is shifting, okay, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Frank Zane, some earbent-nute, Mike Menser, Franco Colombo, Serge New Bray. I mean, a lot of these guys were under 200 pounds, if not just a little bit over 200 pounds. Some of the guys today, like I said, man, 350 pounds in the off-season, it's just not attainable. So I think saying that a classic physique guy just doesn't work as hard as a men's open bodybuilder. They don't have the potential of a men's open bodybuilder. I think that's not true. I think there's plenty of guys in classic that could easily be a guy that weighs, you know, 275, 282, 299, beyond stage. But they just don't want to. Take Chris Bumstedt, for example, one of the top classic physique guys, place second last year at the classic physique Olympia. I mean, this is a guy with a big frame, a big structure, a taller guy. I think if this guy wanted to get into men's open bodybuilding, he certainly has the genetics to do so. This guy could be a guy that's 262, 70, on stage. But he chooses not to. It's not that he doesn't have the potential to. It's that he doesn't want to. He wants to look like a classic physique guy. He wants to be a classic physique competitor. But then again, on the other side of the coin, I can see the argument, Breon Ainsley. He used to be a 212 bodybuilder. But he wasn't quite cutting it into 12. He kind of changed up his physique a little bit to make it into a classic physique. And he was very successful in classic physique. So there's another example where I could see you could say it's quote unquote easier than bodybuilding. But I think for the most part, the mentality is the main thing that's changing. I think people want to write off classic physique and say, it's just an easier division. It's only growing because it's easy. There's only a lot of people interested in it because it's easy. And I don't think that's the case at all. I think classic physique is popular and growing because the mindset, like I've said, is shifting. And that's what people want to look like. So I get the argument. I see where it's coming from. I see what it's based in. But I think overall, the main interest in classic physique is that people are starting to want to look like that. Whereas, yeah, they might have wanted to use to look like, you know, the incredible hawk and he man, they might have seen, you know, Marcus rule back in the day, man, I want to be giant like that. But now I think they're looking back and saying, man, we don't need to look like that. That's not healthy. That's not what I want to do to my body. We can do this, do it in a more healthy way. Now granted, all admit, I mean, these pro-classic physique guys, they're taken steroids too. I mean, these guys aren't natural, men's open body builders. They're not natural either. But the classic physique guys aren't pushing their bodies to such extremes that the men's open body builders are. And I think it's really, really good for the sport because it's going to bring a lot more mainstream attention to it. It's going to look a lot more attainable. A lot of these guys, they could have crossover careers in Hollywood. They have mainstream appeal. They don't have to be this big mass monster that can't do anything else. I mean, these guys can still be active and have careers outside of body building. So let's think overall classic physique is a great thing. He was much smaller both in a stand point of height and a stand point of muscle mass than many of the competitors in the 90s and the early 2000s. Lee Priest stood only five foot four inches tall, weighing roughly in the 220s on stage. It's the fact that the coach that he has coaching him for this bodybuilding show is honey Rambot. Now honey Rambot is the same guy that coaches four-time Mr. Olympia, Jeremy Boyne, Dia, and more notably seven-time Mr. Olympia feel heath. I always think that's interesting and I always think that's good for the sport because it potentially brings people from the other side to the bodybuilding side to watch what happens. We just enjoy seeing, you know, what the potential is for someone to push their body on stage. And it's something that most of us are never going to do. 99% of us, I would say, if you've ever walked around a body building expo, you can look around a lot of them are younger guys, most of them are gym rats, college age guys, high school age guys. Most of them are never going to be on an IFB stage. Myself is included in that category. I like watching the UFC, but I don't want to get my face beaten, but it's fun to watch two guys beat each other's faces in. So the point that I'm getting at man is just because I'm a fan of pro body building. It doesn't mean I'm a fan of competing and it's certainly not something that I want to do. Very often, it just takes a lot of time and energy and effort. There's really no monetary gain whatsoever from being a natural body builder, because you're spending a ton of money on entry fees and food and supplements or whatever have you, and you're making no money in return. So it's really, it's not cost effective, it's not time effective. Under depleting your body multiple times a year, it's just something that, you know, that's got to be your career. If you want to be a pro natural body builder, and you want to focus on that 24-7, that better be your career, you better be training other natural body builders, and you better be making money from your physique alone. And that's something I never want to do. I never want to be the guy that makes money just off of his physique. I want to have other things going in business rather than just being a guy that competes all the time and people know me as that perennial competitor. It's just not something I'm really that interested in. I'm much more interested in the media side of things and bringing information to people. The way it works is man, the IRS, they just don't want you to win. They don't want anybody to get ahead. If you finally find a hustle for yourself and you find a way to make money on the side, where you're not having to work in nine to five all the time, and you can make a decent amount of money off of something that's not traditional, the IRS is going to take their piece of that pie. You better believe they're going to take as much as they can. If you get ahead through a non-traditional means, they're going to take as much as they can on that pie that you got, and they're going to eat the shit out of it. So that's the thing that a lot of YouTubers don't talk about is the fact that, yeah, you can make money on YouTube, but I'm looking at paying over 50% of my income in taxes. That's what I'm looking at right now for the tax being a self-employed YouTuber. So yeah, you can make money, but taxes are going to be a bitch. And that's the thing that comes back to buy a lot of YouTubers in the ass is that YouTube doesn't automatically take taxes out of your checks. So you've got all this money coming into your bank account that you haven't paid taxes on yet. So a lot of people are going to go ahead and spend that money before tax season comes around. And they don't know what's coming. Tax season comes. They owe $60,000. They've spent all the money they've made on YouTube. And they're screwed. Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's driving power. So I've got a little bit more information for you guys now about the fan voting at the 2018 Mr. Olympia. So a couple of days ago, American Media Inc or AMI, which is essentially the company behind the Mr. Olympia put out an official press release regarding the fan voting. So there's a couple of things I wanted to talk about in this press release that really stood out to me here. So in this press release they talk about how the voting is going to happen. So this is something we've all been wondering about, you know, how are the people going to cast votes? Is it going to be an app they can download on their phone? Is it going to be something online? Is it going to be a physical vote? How's it going to happen? So in this article, they actually discuss how it's going to happen. So they say, ticket holders for the judging round on Friday and the finals on Saturday will receive a special code with which they can evaluate each competitor and cast their votes on their phones. The fan votes will be added up and collectively counted as one vote, joining the votes of the judges on the panel. So that's kind of what we thought on the fan vote would just be an additional vote like an additional judge at the table collectively added up. So it appears there's not going to be any kind of special devices or anything. It's just going to be a code given out, probably an app or something you text in your vote from your seat. To explain that a little bit more, essentially how bodybuilding judging works is that the lowest score becomes the winner of the Mr. Olympia. So the voting is based on what placing the judges think you have. So obviously, if every judge votes you in first place and you get six votes for one, your score would be six and that would be the lowest score. So you would win because the most people voted for you in first. So if all the judges vote for you in second, your score would be 12, so 12 versus six, six wins. So it looks to me the fan voting is going to be which bodybuilder gets the most votes for first place from the fan and that vote will be added to the judging panel. So for instance, let's say fill he gets all votes from the judges for first place and let's say big Romney gets straight votes for second. So you're going to have a score of six to 12, which you see that number theoretically. Let's say all the fans vote for big Romney to win the show. So big Romney has all other votes for second and then one fan vote for first place. That fan vote isn't going to help big Romney. It's not going to make him win the Olympia. And that's an area. Then they crown big Romney the people's champion and the fans vote doesn't really change anything. However, there have been many decisions in the past and bodybuilding where it comes down to a one point decision. So you could say let's say it's a tie. So let's say three judges have a guy in second, but three judges have that guy in first. Then the other guy is the same story. Three votes for second, three votes for first. They would have the same score. That in the fan vote in there, that one point could make a difference. So there is kind of a rare scenario where the fan vote could make a difference. But in the most likely case, the fans vote is going to end up being the lowest score. And since the lowest and highest scores are always thrown out to eliminate bias in bodybuilding, the fan vote is probably going to be thrown out most of the time. And it won't really change a result unless it's a very, very close decision in which case it could change a result. So there is the potential that it could matter. But I would say in most cases, the fan vote isn't going to change a whole lot at the Olympia decision. But the other interesting thing that stood out to me about this press release is the way they kind of presented Phil Heath almost in a negative light in this article. So they went to go and kind of quote basically the main challenges to the Olympia title. You got a quote from William Bonac, a quote from Sean Rodin, a quote from Dexter Jackson. Where all these guys are saying the fan voting is a great idea. And finally, they go down to Phil Heath and they say, and I quote, interestingly enough, Phil Heath, the current Mr. Olympia who will be going for his record, a Sandout trophy, had no comment on the fan voting. So it almost looks like they tried to frame this press release as it's a possibility that Phil Heath could be defeated because of this fan voting thing, which, you know, it makes sense. They want to generate hype around the fan voting and they want to present this idea in the back of people's minds that they're going to be able to change a result. And really the reason I think this is because if Phil Heath had no comment, they could have just not included Phil Heath at all, but they wanted to make sure they pointed out that Phil Heath had no comment. Because they knew exactly how that would look in the press release, having all these guys saying it's great and finally end it with Phil Heath saying no comment or they could have just left out the Phil Heath part entirely. === FILE: Olympia Winners that kept their gains after retiring [CFAy3X0HY_s].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick Shonda Powers. I thought a good idea for a video would be past Mr Olympia winners that were able to maintain their physics over the years. So in this video we're going to go through some of those guys that didn't lose their gains and were able to maintain a pretty impressive physique. Well after their Olympia wins. So we're going to start with the very first ever Mr Olympia winner Larry Scott who won the inaugural 1965 Mr Olympia competition and he also won the 1966 Mr Olympia competition. Then he retired in his 20s and he would make a 1979 comeback somewhere in his mid 40s still looking very impressive after taking over a 13 year high 80s from the sport of body building. But it's not just his comeback in his 40s that was impressive. He maintained his physique all the way up until his death pretty much. This photo that you're looking at here where he's hitting a bicep shot, he is 73 years old in that photo compared to a photo of him in his 20s from the 1960s. So this guy maintained his physique all the way until the end. First Mr Olympia ever arguably won the most impressive examples of a guy that was able to maintain his physique. Now next up we have the second Mr Olympia ever and that would be Sergio Aliva. So Sergio Aliva won the 1967, 1968 and 1969 Mr Olympia competitions making him the first ever three time Mr Olympia and at the time the winning is Mr Olympia ever until the reign of Arnold Schwarzenegger would come a few years later. I'm then as he got a little bit older and age as physique would slack a little bit but that just really comes with the territory of getting older but for the most part he did an incredible job of maintaining his physique after his Olympia wins. But prior to that, and still is known as being one of the best powerlifters in the world, raw powerlifters in the 275 pound weight class. Now his most recent world record was in the 275 pound weight class back in November of 2017, where he had a total of 2,275 pounds with an 855 pound deadlift, an 810 pound squat, and a 610 pound bench press, which became an all-time world record at 275. So in addition to that, Larry Wheels is a pretty young guy, so I think as a powerlifter he has probably the most potential out of anybody to be one of the greatest powerlifters of all time, and if he continues the pursuit bodybuilding and work on his physique in that regard, he could be one of the strongest bodybuilders of all time, which brings me to my number one spot. So in number one, we have the pro bodybuilder, and also elite level powerlifter world record setting powerlifter stand-efforting. So stand-efforting is the only bodybuilder's slash powerlifter on this list, the whole that is stinction of being a world record holding powerlifter and an IFPP pro bodybuilder. So he became the best in the world of powerlifting, and then competed with the best in the world in bodybuilding. Now you earned his IFPP pro card back in 2009 at the NPC Master's Nationals, where he won the Super Heavyweight Division in the overall which gave him his pro card. You're going to compete in the pros about four or five times, 2010 placing 16th at the Phoenix Pro, 2010 also placing 14th at the Orlando, Europa, 2011 placing 9th at the Flex Pro, and 2012 again placing 13th at the Flex Pro. So the most interesting thing about stand-efforting, and this is part of the reason I have him in the number one spot is that he set some of his most impressive world records during the time he was competing in pro bodybuilding. So keep in mind I mentioned he competed in 2011 and 2012. So in powerlifting in 2011 he set his best raw total with no knee wraps which was 2,226 pounds which was a world record at time. And that was in the 275 pound weight class. === FILE: Powerlifting Legend Terry Todd passes away at age 80 [kmkEYUVyjdM].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's time to power. So I kind of wanted to do a quick video, paying respect to Dr. Terry Todd. So if you don't know who Terry Todd was, he was a guy who had a tremendous impact on the sport of strong man. And was really one of the people responsible for the Arnold Classic Strongman competition, which is really the second most well known competition to the world strongest man. Now during the 60s Terry Todd was a weightlifter in powerlifting himself, but most importantly in note worthy, is his contribution to chronicling the history of strength sports, strong man, powerlifting, bodybuilding, in general, him and his wife are actually responsible for the founding of the H.J. Luther Stark Center for Physical Culture and Sports, which is essentially a museum, which is housed in Texas, Memorial Stadium at the University of Texas. It is one of the largest collections chronicling the history of strength sports in general and competitive lifting, covering strong man, strong woman sports nutrition, bodybuilding, naturopathy, conditioning for athletes, drug use, and the sport in strength sports. More than 150,000 books, photos, films, magazines, letters, training courses, video tapes, posters, paintings, and artifacts, just one of the largest collections of the history of the sport was created by this man. But I would say one of the biggest things would be the Arnold Classic Strongman that he was responsible for. He created most of the events that were held. They're all the different lifts and all that stuff. Most of them were created by Terry Todd. And I wanted to share this post with you guys from Arnold Schwarzenegger himself, which he posted on Reddit shortly after Terry Todd Dodgers. Here's what Schwarzenegger had to say. I'm about Terry Todd passing. He said, I tweeted this, but Terry was so important to me. I wanted to share with you guys. He was more than a fantastic partner for the Arnold Strongman series. He was a dear friend. I remember the first time I saw Terry Todd and Gold's GM after I moved here, lifting weights that I couldn't believe. He was such a monster, a true force, but also a kind heart and a great storyteller. He used his powers to be a fantastic leader for the fitness crusade. He was an ambassador of strength, the historian of health, the advocate for iron. My thoughts are with his family and my work out tomorrow is for him. I hope you'll join me in dedicating your lifts to Terry. So Terry Todd passed away on July 7th, 2018. He was 80 years old. Thank you guys for watching the video. Next time I have a power signing out.

Back in 1965, the Olympia started with men's open body building. But the interesting thing is starting in the 70s, I believe it was 1974, they actually did introduce the over 200 and under 200 categories in body building. So someone would win the over 200 and someone would win the under 200 and those two winners would go head to head for the overall title of Mr. Olympia. And you guys may remember that best from Arnold and Franco going head to head, Franco winning the under and Arnold winning the over. So that would go on for a while and that would really be a big reason why Frank Zane would go on to win three Mr. Olympias. That would be a reason why Franco won the Olympia in 1976, although they would do away with this in 1980. So it didn't last very long. It lasted less than a decade, but it was something that was part of body building history where they would have different divisions go head to head for the overall title. So this is not something that hasn't been done before. So the interesting part about this was you could have a classic physique guy, a two 12 guy, and a men's open body building guy go head to head for the Mr. Olympia title. And the guy that one men's open might not be declared men's open Mr. Olympia. They might not be declared Mr. Olympia period. I think that could be a very interesting thing. At the same time it could kind of be sac religious to body building history, but it could also be very interesting because we did have this in the 70s. And that's what we saw with the pumping iron documentary. We saw that over and under 200 and that made the documentary even more interesting because it had that dynamic to the Mr. Olympia. So my question to you guys is, do you think this would be a good idea at the Mr. Olympia to see Breon, Phil Heath, Flex Lewis, or whoever ends up winning these divisions in the future go head to head for the sole title of Mr. Olympia. So this isn't something that hasn't been done before. Again, I'll reiterate that because it's not like, you know, this is kind of a brand new idea. This is something that has been done. So it's not something that couldn't be done in the future. It's certainly an actual possibility because this has been done before. So let me know what you guys think in the comment section below. === FILE: Short VS Long Biceps [9hJf06b6Vo4].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's Giant of Power. So in this video I wanted to talk about the difference between a quote unquote short bicep and long bicep head. So you're going to see two different kinds of biceps and bodybuilding primarily. So the first kind, I think one of the best examples of the long muscle belly is going to be looking at Larry Scott. So Larry Scott was one of the most famous bodybuilders in terms of having that long muscle belly and having really good arms at the same time. So basically when someone refers to a bicep as being a long bicep or a long bicep head, what they're referring to is a long muscle belly with a short tendon where the muscle pretty much extends all the way to the forearm when flex from the front. So that's what a long bicep looks like from the forearm to the shoulder. So when people refer to a short bicep or a short bicep head, what they're referring to there is a short muscle belly with a long tendon. So when you flex the bicep from the front, the bicep looks kind of similar to a heart and it has a much better peak or a much more pronounced peak than a long bicep. And typically in that front double bicep, you can see the tendon between the bicep muscle and the forearm in the front double bicep. Where's the long muscle belly? You can't see that tendon. Now I think if we look back at past Mr. Olympia winners and try to find a Mr. Olympia, that best exemplified that short bicep head. I think Ronnie Coleman or Arnold Schwarzenegger would be too very good examples of the short bicep head. Now another fascinating thing about the long versus short biceps is that typically throughout bodybuilding history, there've been a lot of famous rivalries between a Mr. Olympia and a Mr. Olympia runner-up where each guy had a different inserted bicep. So if we go back to the early Mr. Olympia as you take Sergio Leva for example, another guy where they long bicep head, you can see the bicep because all the way to the forearm very long and thick bicep. He had a rivalry with Arnold Schwarzenegger, very famous for having the very peaked, very short bicep heads. Then in the pumping iron documentary Arnold versus Lou Ferrigno, Lou Ferrigno guy again who has famously long bicep heads, Arnold having famously short bicep heads. Fast forward to more modern times. I'll say Phil Heath is an example of a guy that has a long bicep head and Kai Green has a very very peaked and very very short bicep heads and they're one of the greatest bodybuilding rivalries of all time. So I think the fascinating difference between these two different pifter bicep heads typically ends in these two guys both being very impressive bodybuilders and really coming down to the separation between first and second at the Olympia. So I also wanted to throw in this video a couple of extreme examples of a short bicep head. A very extremely peaked bicep to the point where the shape of the bicep is almost distorted looking. So this example here is going to be Leonard St. Sears. So this guy is a UK bodybuilder and this guy has one of the craziest bicep peaks I've ever seen. I mean a lot of people say it's so peaked that it doesn't even look aesthetic or appealing to them and almost looks weird. It doesn't even look normal. It is a very very extreme case of a short bicep head and a very peaked bicep. And then of course a lot of people refer to the shape of a short bicep head as a heart-shaped bicep. And I think the best example of that would be Albert Beckles. Albert Beckles, you know, his bicep is really dead on resembled a heart like turned on its side. So I think he's a perfect example of that analogy of a short head bicep being heart-shaped. And one of the questions that I get a lot that's kind of a misconception about short versus long muscle bellies is how do I train my muscle belly to be short or long? And the answer to that question is you can't. It's just simply genetics. You're born with one muscle belly or the other. And you got to do your best to train it. You don't really have an option of being short or long. You're just born that way. And I would say a perfect example of this would be Sergio Aliva and his son Sergio Aliva Jr. I mean they have very, very similar arms. They both have long muscle belly biceps. And that's a perfect example of those muscle bellies genetics being passed on from one generation to another genetically. So I hope you guys enjoyed the video. Maybe found it interesting. Please give the video a thumbs up if you enjoyed it. Next track from Power, signing out.

You start to try to put on muscle you cut down and you realize I don't really put on that much muscle. I just got fat. So then you're starting to think, man, you know, I'm training. I've been training hard. I've been training long. I've been training for years. And I'm not really seeing much if any change to my physique at this point again, especially for natural guys. So you start to question. I mean, is the steroid route that I should go? Should I do something to take my physique to the next level? And I think that is the question that a lot of you guys are asking. And as a question that I get all the time, should I take steroids? Do I have what it takes to be an IPB pro bodybuilder? This is my physique naturally. What do you think? Do you think I would look steroids? I could take the next level. Take that question all the time. So in this video, I kind of wanted to answer that in a general sense. I think if you're natural and you're even questioning whether or not to take steroids. If it's in the back of your mind that you shouldn't or there's any doubt in your mind that you don't want to take steroids, I think you should not take steroids. You guys think the people that become IPB pro bodybuilders, the people that make it to the Mr. Olympia, the people that compete at the top level, there's no doubt in their minds what they're going to do what it takes to get to that level. So if you have any doubt, I think you know deep down that's not the route that you want to take and that's not the route you want to go, but you're feeling pressure to go that route. So you're asking people like me, should I go that route? So if you're asking, I think you probably shouldn't take that route. And it's really a matter of what's the risk to benefit ratio on doing this. If you take steroids, what is it you're really going to achieve from doing it? Is it going to be a financial gain? Is it going to be a confidence gain? Is it going to be, I'm going to get more followers on social media? I mean, what is the main benefit? You need to ask yourself from doing this. Are you just doing it for yourself? Are you doing it to impress other people? And I think if you're doing it to impress others, it's really something that you should probably not do. I mean, if you're really doing it because you feel there's an expectation, externally for you to do it, you probably shouldn't do it. If you're not doing it for yourself, I certainly feel you should not take steroids. And you've got to think about the risk, man. I mean, Louis Marko has been doing a great job in his recent videos. He's been doing a series where he talks about the truth of the fitness industry. He's been saying in those videos, you have these guys that made the decision to take steroids at a very young age. A lot of these guys can never go back to being natural because they've shut down their natural hormone production and they have to stay on these hormones for the rest of their life. And that's a very good point. You've got to think about life after bodybuilding. I mean, even if you made it to a national level in PC show, even if you made it to the IFB, you've got to think about your life after bodybuilding. Is that a commitment that you're willing to make to put those hormones in your body for the rest of your life? Because you've now done so much damage to your system that it can't maintain homeostasis on its own. So that's really something we all need to think about as what's the risk to reward from a health standpoint, from a commitment standpoint. And what's going to look like for the rest of your life after bodybuilding because bodybuilding is a very temporary state, especially if you're doing it as a career, the pro bodybuilders. I mean, what do they have about a decade of being on top, if they're on top and after a decade they start to taper off. Some guys even a much shorter pro career than that. So you got to think about that, man. While I am a big fan of pro bodybuilding, I like to see these guys push the limit because they're passionate about. They've made that decision that they're going to do whatever it takes. That doesn't necessarily mean it's for you or me to make that same decision. But we can still enjoy watching the process of them achieve their goals, of them push their physique, of them show us what a human physique can look like if you take it to the extreme. But I thought it was really important for me to make that point that even though I'm a fan of this, it's not something I would ever choose for myself. I think to health risk certainly outweighs any benefit for me because if I ever took steroids, I wouldn't be doing it for myself because I know deep down steroids isn't something that I ever want to do. It's not something I want to put my body through. And if I did it, it would be to impress you guys. It would be to impress people on the internet. It would be to, you know, give more attention for myself, give more followers based on my physique. I think that's just a very vain and selfish pursuit. I mean, you really got to think about yourself first before you think about what others think about how you look. Personally, I chose a natural route because, hey, I want to be healthy. I want to have a, you know, I want to have a good physique for myself. It builds my confidence. It's something I enjoy doing. I do it because I enjoy working out. I do it because I enjoy watching the changes that I make to my body. I don't do it necessarily because, hey, you know, these people are going to think I've got big arms. I'm doing it because I really like the workout and I really like to be healthy and I really enjoy the process. It's a really fun thing to do for me. And again, that raises the question, if you decide to take steroids, are you doing it because you enjoy the process or are you doing it because you want to impress others? So I just wanted to make this video because I know a lot of you younger guys out there right now are probably feeling a lot of pressure to take steroids. And a lot of older guys on my channel will tell you, I see them commented all the time as well. You know, I'm 55 years old. I'm 65 years old and I've been natural in my entire life and they always say in the comments section, I want these younger guys to see my comment because I've been doing this for 30, 40 years training and enjoying the process and I haven't put my health in jeopardy during that entire period of time. The supplement companies appear to be larger than life with these massive followings on social media, specifically on Instagram. In the main company that I'm noticing here was one of the biggest companies in the supplement game in the fitness industry. You guys may remember a company by the name of Shredds, S-H-R-E-D-Z. Now back when Shredds was really at its peak, they were kind of infamous for signing athletes that weren't really actual athletes. They were mostly signing people that were other social media influencers or just guys with good physique or girls with good physique that simply just had a large following for really whatever reason. In a lot of those athletes ended up having a lot of controversies of their own regarding Photoshop or scamming people out of money. If these people had training programs, they were selling. Some of these guys got exposed for having an assistant right up these plans for their clients in the actual athlete themselves didn't have any involvement. Shredds already didn't have the best track record. But one of my followers actually pointed out to me on Instagram that Shredds has two million followers. But on their posts, they average one to 200 likes on each of their photos. Typically, almost everything that they pose, that's like 90% of it. I'd say 99% of it is going to be under a thousand likes and probably 75% of it is going to be under 500 likes and a lot of their recent stuff is going to be under 200 likes in some cases even under 100 likes. And again, they claim to have 2 million followers on Instagram, 2 million real followers they claim. So obviously something's not right with that. You've got 2 million followers and 200 people are liking your pictures on average. I've only got 20 something thousand followers and pretty much anything that I post averages 2 to 3 thousand likes. About a 10% or more engagement rate. So I actually went and did some research on the average Instagram engagement rates. So based on how many followers you have, what on average would be the number of people that should like one of your posts or view one of your posts. According to influence.co's engagement report as of April 2017, for an account with over 1 million followers, the typical engagement percentage is 1.5%. So if you do the math on that, the average engagement percentage for someone with 1 million followers would be 1.5%. If you have 1 million followers, that would be an average of 15,000 likes per post. Now keep in mind, shreds has 2 million followers. So technically, according to this percentage, an average account with 2 million followers should be getting about 30,000 likes per post, that's 1.5%. Now clearly, the photos posted on the shreds account are beneath the average, expected engagement rate for an account of that size. And not only are they just beneath that average, they don't come anywhere close to that average of 30,000. Again, it looks like in 90% of the cases, their photos don't even get a thousand likes on them. And then like I said, some of their recent posts even get less than 100 likes, so like 70 likes, 70 likes is less than 0.001% engagement. And it should be around 1.5% on average. They're not even close to that. So this video is just to serve as another reminder. There's a lot of things to watch out for in this fitness industry. There's a lot of people willing to do whatever it takes. Whatever fake thing they need to do, whether it's followers, weights, fake body parts, the photos shop, their pictures. They are willing to go to these extremes to sell their product or to get that extra follower. They're willing to do it. And shreds, unfortunately, is just one example of the many supplement companies that are probably buying fake followers to appear like they're a larger brand than they really are. And perhaps by appearing to have a larger following, it gives them the appearance of being a more reputable brand, a more popular brand. It's going to make people want to buy their product if they see oh, 2 million people are following the supplement company. They must have a pretty decent product. Do you or you more likely to buy a product from a supplement company that has 10,000 followers on social media or a company that has 2 million? I mean, it's basically just a marketing tactic. And it appears to me now, you can never know for sure, but it would appear to me, a large majority of shreds followers are probably either fake or just a large majority of them don't care about anything shreds has the post, which will also suggest that those followers are possibly purchased. This kind of bought accounts or accounts that don't really care about what shreds is posting. So, let me know what you guys think in the comment section below about supplement companies potentially having fake followers online. And please comment in the comment section below if you know of a company doing something similar to this. So the topic of this video is going to be tattoos and bodybuilding and whether or not they are okay as in, do they hurt your placings? Can you be successful with tattoos and bodybuilding? Do tattoos have a place in bodybuilding. Now it's the direction things are headed right now. This generation, you got the 5% crew really popularizing the idea of being a freak and having tattoos all of your body and really associating tattoos with bodybuilding. And I would say right now in 2018 tattoos are probably more acceptable and more popular than they ever have been in the past. And as a result of that, you are seeing more and more competitors, especially in the amateur ranks, competing with tattoos and not just small tattoos but significant tattoos like covering their entire arms, maybe covering their entire chest, giant back tattoos for example. So I want to talk about my opinion in this video of whether or not tattoos and bodybuilding, are really that big of a deal and whether or not they're going to hurt your placings. So I think first of this example, you need to look at the best bodybuilders in the world. And that is past and present, Mr. Olympia winner. So feel Heath, Jay Cutler, Ronnie Coleman, Lee Haney, none of those Mr. Olympias ever had tattoos anywhere on their body. But if you look back to Dory and Yates Dory and Yates actually did have a couple tattoos, specifically on his forearms. So tattoos just having one or two small tattoos is not going to hurt you that bad in judging and the judges really don't care that much. Now again, Dory and had his tattoos maybe two decades ago now when he won those Olympias. So obviously it wasn't that big of a taboo thing, even though back in the 90s tattoos weren't nearly as acceptable. So it's not like the judges are going to see a single tattoo on your body and say, okay, we're going to hurt this guy's placing. So we do have one Mr. Olympia winner in Dory and Yates that did have tattoos. You can go back to 2006 and I think Lee Priest is a very good example of this back in 2006. And back then he had a pretty significant amount of tattoos, not nearly as many as he had now, but covering a significant portion of his arms, specifically his shoulders, but he still was able to do very well in the IAPV and won some pro shows, even having those tattoos. The tank that the body builders put on the spray tank, they have certain blends of these pro-tans that are meant to mask or cover tattoos. So really, the technology as far as tanning goes today, you can cover up or mask pretty much a majority of any tattoos that you're going to have if you have the proper tan. And he also had a tattoo on his arms, clearly the judges saw straight past that and gave him second place at the Aron Classic, eighth place at the Olympia, a very high level placing for someone with a tattoo. So honestly, I think from a judging standpoint, it's not going to hurt you that bad. It might hurt you a little bit, but overall it's not going to prevent you from winning a show. It's not going to prevent you from placing highly. It may take away to some degree from your physique. But overall, it's not really going to hurt your placings that drastically. Now that being said, my personal opinion is, although they might not hurt your judging too much, if you're a pro body builder, I think it's probably not a good idea to cover your body and tattoos. I mean, I know that tattoos really come down to personal preference and how you see your own body and what you want your own body to look like. But if you are a professional body builder, it doesn't really matter so much what you think about your body. I think the forearms of the calves would probably be the two least impactful places that you could get a tattoo as far as judging goes, as far as overall perception goes. I mean when you start getting tattoos that cover your largest muscle groups, such as your chest, your shoulders, your back, covering your legs, or even the people that get these giant like midsection tattoos on the side of their midsection, I think those are the kind of tattoos that if your place can be hurt, those are the tattoos that are going to hurt your place. So overall, my opinion is I don't think tattoos in body building are that big of a deal. But when people talk about the Mr. America title just keep in mind that the AAU is the oldest and most respected Mr. America title there is. There was just the Mr. Universe. So the very first Mr. Universe title ever won was won by John Germek in 1948 where he defeated the legendary Steve Reeves to win that title. So you could say John Germek played a key role in the formation of NAVA by winning that first ever Mr. Universe and promoting that first ever Mr. Universe which would become one of the most prestigious and longest running titles in the history of body building the NAVA Mr. Universe title which would become more sought after in some cases than the Mr. Olympia title. So then in 1949 John Germek would go on to win the Mr. USA title making him a two-time Mr. America first Mr. Universe winner and Mr. USA winner. Which arguably changed the course of weightlifting history in America forever with that 1936 Olympic team that basically was trained out of York Barbell. Now just to give you guys some frame of reference for how strong he really was his body weight was between 215 and 225 pounds or 93 to 102.1 kilograms standing at a height of 5 foot 8 inches tall or 172.5 centimeters. Now at that height and weight his best bench press was 480 pounds his best deadlift was 600 pounds and his best squat was 700 pounds. Now keep in mind this was during the 1930s and 1940s it's not like it is today and you know a 600 pound deadlift was not an everyday thing this was not something you're seeing you know all the time on Instagram like you see today a 600 pound deadlift in the 30s and 40s was a very rare feat of strength. In the same could be said for a 5-plate bench press back then I mean that was just an insane feat of strength for someone during that era and John Germek was doing all of these things. One of the best body builders to come out of that era one of the pound for pounds strongest men to come out of that era. One of the most groundbreaking body builders to come out of that era winning two inaugural titles of two of the competitions that would become the longest running. === FILE: The Legend Bruno Sammartino [3TddotAgPdI].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's time to power and I wanted to make another wrestling themed video specifically about the wrestler Bruno Sam Artino because unfortunately just last week he passed away at the age of 82 years old. Now not only was Bruno Sam Artino a legendary wrestler but he was also a very very strong power lifter. In fact he set a legitimate bench press record back in 1959 and I'm not talking about a fake record that was made up for his wrestling character something that was kind of invented to make him seem stronger back in 1959 he set a legitimate world record and he was the first man to bench over 500 pounds. So before Bruno in the early 1950s those a guy named Doug Hepburn who is the first man to bench press 450 and then 500 pounds and that a couple years later in 1959 Bruno Sam Artino would become the first man ever to press 565 pounds. So not only did he break and set a world record he beat the previous record by 65 pounds that is a massive leap from one record to another. In fact it gave you guys some perspective of how big of a jump 65 pounds is from one record to another all the bench press world records going back to 1996 and this is raw bench presses. So from 96 to 2018 they have all been in the low 700 so in 1996 the bench press record was 705 pounds and now currently in 2018 the current record is 739 pounds. So in 22 years the raw bench press record has only increased roughly 34 pounds. So for Bruno Sam Artino to shatter that record like he did especially back in the 1950s I mean a 565 bench back then was just an insanely impressive feat of strength. In back when he completed that bench press he was actually relatively small compared to the size that he would be as a pro wrestler he's about 6 foot tall or a little bit under weighing about 260 pounds and it was this initial bench press record that would catch the attention of Vince McMahon senior and originally you know the reason he brought Bruno Sam Artino over into his wrestling organization. So that big bench press would essentially be the start of Bruno Sam Artino's career. So back in the late 50s early 60s after he set that bench press record that would be where Bruno Sam Artino started his career with the WWF and that was the worldwide wrestling federation which would later become the WWF the world wrestling federation which of course would later become the WWE world wrestling entertainment. Now Bruno Sam Artino also had one of the longest-raining title reigns in wrestling history lasting nearly eight years when he won his first WWWF World Heavyweight Championship so seven years eight months and one day to be exact and then his second title run with the WWWF would last almost three years and five months. So if you guys didn't realize how iconic of a wrestler Bruno Sam Artino was his title run all together in the WWF with last over 10 years if you combine the two title reigns and then later on in his career he would come back to the WWF in 1984 and that would last till about 1988. I'm when during that time he would win the intercontinental heavyweight championship and he would also appear at WrestleMania. Now another interesting thing about Bruno Sam Artino's pro wrestling careers he is one of the very few wrestlers to have a match with somebody where the other person actually died likely as a result of that match. So Bruno Sam Artino in 1961 had a match with a wrestler named Chick Garibaldi. I'm enduring that match Bruno Sam Artino body slam Chick Garibaldi to the canvas and he did not get back up and the referee came over, stopped the match and determined that Chick Garibaldi was dead on the spot. The cause of death will later be determined as a heart attack and then this photo right here is a pretty interesting photo that I came across. So in this photo he's signing an autograph for a woman named Kathy Seagull and for those of you that don't know she was actually a female body builder that would go on to win the Miss International Competition in 1987 which is one of the biggest competitions in female body building and she actually had a very impressive physique during her body building career.
