=== FILE: The Myth： Sergio Oliva [lNLYue_6AZQ].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's Time of Power so today I wanted to make a video on Sergio O'Liva. Now I've done a couple of videos on Sergio in the past but I've never really done a full complete profile of Sergio and his competition history. I've talked about some of his rivalries with Arnold Schwarzenegger. Some of the times when they went head to head and the outcome was controversial. I've also talked about Sergio's comeback in 1984. But I wanted to make a more standalone video about Sergio's kind of detailing all the things that he achieved during his career, his posing, his accolades, his Mr. Olympia wins, his rivalry with Joe Weater. All the things that contributed to making him the body builder that he was remembered to be. So Sergio O'Liva would begin his competitive career in body building in 1964, competing in the AAU, Mr. America, where he took seventh place. In 1966, he had won his first junior Mr. America and then in 1966 he would also win the IFPB Mr. World. Then he would compete in his first Mr. Olympia ever to the 1966 Olympia where he placed fourth and obviously 1966 is the final year that Larry Scott won the Olympia. Larry Scott won the first Olympia ever in 65. When his second Olympia in 66 and then he would retire from body building. So Sergio would win his first of three Mr. Olympia titles beginning in 1967. So he would win 67, 68 and 69, making him a three-time Mr. Olympia winner at that time that was the record for most Olympia wins. During that time he also won the 67 IFPB Mr. Universe competition. Now in 1970, history would be made and this would kind of mark the coming of Arnold Schwarzenegger. Arnold would actually defeat Sergio O'Liva, the Raining Mr. Olympia at the 1970 AAU Mr. World competition which was held just before the 1970 Mr. Olympia which would be the Olympia where Arnold would finally de-throne Sergio O'Liva and win his first of seven Olympia titles. So Sergio being defeated in 1978 that Mr. World competition is a very important moment in body building history. Now even though the Mr. Olympia wasn't that old yet this would be the first time in history as I mentioned that a Raining Mr. Olympia would be defeated outside of the Mr. Olympia competition. And this would not happen again until 2002 where Gunter Sler Camp defeated five-time Mr. Olympia at the time Ronnie Coleman at the 2002 GNC show of strength just weeks after the Mr. Olympia. So this is something that has happened very few times in body building history seeing a Raining Mr. Olympia get defeated off the Olympia stage. Now Sergio and Joe Weeder would have a lot of ups and downs during Sergio's body building career and this would really begin in 1970-slash 71 where Sergio decided to go over to NABBA and compete in the Mr. Universe. So NABBA was the rival organization to the IFBB. I've said this many times but prior to the IFBB the NABBA Mr. Universe was the number one most sought after title in body building. So Sergio went over there to compete for that title placing second in the 1971 NABBA Mr. Universe. Now the note worthy thing about this is 1971 was the here the IFBB implemented their non-sanctioned policy in their body building competition. So what that meant was if you competed in a rival Federation and you were an IFBB pro body builder you could be banned or disqualified from upcoming Mr. Olympia competitions. And that's exactly what happened to Sergio in 1971 where he was banned from competing at the Mr. Olympia and as a result in 1971 Arnold Schwarzenegger was actually the only competitor to compete in that years of Olympia. And Sergio was not allowed but he was allowed to guess pose at that show. So that is why you will see photos of Sergio on the Olympia stage in 1971 posing but it was simply a guess posing. He was not a competitor in the 1971 Mr. Olympia. Now the 1972 Mr. Olympia would be where the rivalry between Joe Weater and Sergio at Levo really come to peak because in 1972 Sergio placed second to Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sergio claims he deserved a win that show and many other body building fans think Sergio won in 1972 as well. And he went on to say that after he placed second Joe Weater told him that his ban from the Olympia was still in effect and that is why he got second place and did not win the show. And Sergio there's kind of a lot of controversy about this but in Sergio's own words that's what happened. So after that 1972 Mr. Olympia Sergio became very disgruntled and he was obviously upset at the fact that you know why would they let him compete if his ban was still in place why would they place him second? Why would he have even been at the Mr. Olympia if he was still banned? He thought it was kind of a bogus excuse for you know Joe Weater allowing Arnold the win because Arnold was obviously Joe Weater's golden boy and you know he saw Arnold as the future of body building. So Sergio felt that the competition was rigged in favor of Arnold and you know the whole ban thing was just kind of an excuse. So is it this point that Sergio made a major move that would piss off Joe Weater and that would be to go compete and Joe Weater's main rival Dan Loury. His body building organization known as the WBBG or the World Body Building Guild. Dan Loury and Joe Weater have done a whole video on this topic but they were basically rival promoters that had a lot of bad blood between them and when Sergio came over to the WBBG it was a big deal in body building history to have you know a three-time Mr. Olympia basically one of the IIPB's best body builders that come over to another organization. I'm going to start competing for them. So in that video where I talked about Sergio making a comeback to the 1984 Mr. Olympia one of the things that I wanted to mention here was the fact that Sergio never retired from body building. He simply quit competing in the Mr. Olympia from 1972 to 1984 but he was still competing over in the WBBG winning a slew of titles including the WBBG Mr. Galaxy the WBBG Mr. International the WBBG Mr. Olympus which he won about three times. He would compete in the WABBA World Championships which he would win twice and he would also win the WABBA Pro World Cup twice. Now an interesting thing about the WABBA or the World Amateur Body Building Association is this was another rival Federation to the IIPB actually founded by the French Body Builder Serge New Bray who many of you guys may remember from pumping iron he actually founded it the year after pumping iron. So this was another guy that you can argue was pretty disgruntled with his playings in the IIPB. So he went on to start his own organization WABBA. So it was pretty obvious that Sergio was trying to send a message to Joe Weader that he was pissed off and he was going to these other organizations and winning other major titles. So that would bring us to 1984 where Sergio leave a kind of put aside his differences with Joe Weader to compete in the Olympia two more times. So in 1984 at the age of 44 years old Sergeo would come back and compete at the Olympia placing a very respectable eighth place at a very competitive lineup. Now Sergio even said after the fact that he realized there was no chance that Joe Weader would ever let him win another Mr. Olympia title but he wanted to try anyway especially considering the fact that in 1984 Arnold had been retired for four years so he knew he wasn't going to have to go head to head with Arnold anymore so it was kind of a new era and body building. He thought the time was right to jump back on stage. And I've got to say as far as come back, Joe Sergeo leave a very impressive comeback as physique was very impressive, very thick and very dense. You could even make an argument he was bigger than at some points in his career when he was still with the IIPB. So Sergio would compete at the Olympia one final time in 1985 again placing eighth and that would be essentially his retirement from body building. And again that's where you see the iconic photos of Sergio holding up his son on stage. His son obviously Sergio Jr. who is an IFBB pro today. Most notably winning this past year's New York pro competition and how iconic will it be when Sergio finally competes on the Olympia stage he will be the first body builder in history to be a legacy Mr. Olympia competitor and what I mean by legacy is a son of a former Mr. Olympia winner competing in the Mr. Olympia competition has never been done before and it will be a giant moment in body building history when Sergio Jr. decides to step on the last stage. Now unfortunately Sergio Sr. is no longer with us he passed away back in 2012 at the age of 71 years old but he certainly did leave a pretty impactful legacy on body building. Not just in the sense of the titles that he won but his posing as well. I mean his victory pose which he pretty much trade mark became one of the most iconic poses in body building that kind of overhead kind of a variation of a front double bicep pose. Where you've got the lats flared out it shows your V tape or it shows the size of your arms it shows the size of your forearms you've got your quads flexed it was just a very iconic pose for that era and you see many body builders today trying to replicate that pose and very few of them can pull off that pose like Sergio ported off in his prime. I think Lee Priest is one of the few body builders that can pull off that pose in a way that's almost as impressive as Sergio leave us but I think no one will ever have the same victory pose as Sergio. And of course even though Arnold defeated Sergio and took the Olympia title from him Sergio still remains only one of three men to ever defeat Arnold Schwarzenegger and a body building contest so that is a very big distinction. And then of course he had Sergio changing the history of body building by forever changing the rules in the IFBB with that 1971 non-Sanction policy which again many people feel that Sergio leave us with the sole reason that that policy was created and that is a policy that remains in place to this day. And then just a quick overview of Sergio stats I mean he was about 235 pounds on stage or 166 kilograms at a height of 5 foot 10 which for that era and body building was a pretty big body builder. And he also supported a very impressive 27 inch waist which is part of the reason why he had one of the greatest V tapers of all time and a major part of the reason why his victory pose looked as impressive as it did. So that is the video guys I hope you guys enjoyed it please give it a thumbs up if you did enjoy it next strength and power signing out.

=== FILE: The Runner-Up at the First Two Olympias [AMx3JkpdzF0].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the power. So if they want to make a video about an old school body builder by the name of Harold Pool, now Harold Pool is a very interesting body builder for a number of reasons. Number one being the fact that he was the first African American IFB, Mr. American winner. And that was a big deal back in the day because he won that Mr. America back in 1964. And obviously that was over 50 years ago now. So racism back then was a little bit worse than it is now. Probably a lot worse than it is now. I'm back then the body building scene in the 50s and 60s was really pretty much dominated by white winners of these competitions. So Harold Pool was the first guy to kind of break that mold. So that was a very historic moment in body building history. But another thing that's very historic about Harold Pool is that Harold Pool was the first ever runner up at the Mr. Olympia competition. Obviously in 1965 being the first Mr. Olympia ever, he took runner up to Larry Scott. In 1966 he became runner up for the second time again to Larry Scott. In 1966 he also beat Sergio Aliva who took third in 66. And then the following year in 1967 he would compete in the Mr. Olympia competition again being beaten by Sergio Aliva and Chuck Sipes taking third at the 67 Olympia. So he's the only man to have competed in all three of the first three Mr. Olympias. In bear in mind that at that time being a two-time runner up at the Mr. Olympia that was a new record especially two consecutive years. The next guy that would be runner up two times at the Olympia would be Sergio Aliva. But it wouldn't be two consecutive years. It would be in 1970 and also in 1972 because Sergio Aliva was banned from competing at the 1971 Mr. Olympia. So I believe the next person to get two consecutive second place finishes two years in a row would be Muhammad McCaway in the 80s during the reign of Lee Haney. So make no mistake about it. Heropul was one of the best body builders to come out of the 1960s era of body building. During that period winning the title of Mr. America, the title of IAPV Mr. Universe, then in 1971 winning the title of IAPV Mr. USA. So this guy three-time runner up at the Mr. Olympia and then all three of the other biggest titles in body building, the University of America, the USA's, one, all of those as well. And then he would continue competing all the way up until 1982 where he placed ninth at the IAPV World Pro Championships. And then in 2004 he was inducted in the IAPV Hall of Fame. Now all of those major titles that I mentioned up until that point were titles that Heropul won during the prime of his body building career. But the interesting thing about Heropul is that as a teenager, he was arguably one of the best teen body builders of all time. In 1961, placing fourth at the Mr. America at the age of 17, and at that time the Mr. America was one of the biggest titles in body building next to the Mr. Universe. Obviously the Mr. Olympia wouldn't be around for another five years. So at the age of 17, placing fourth to some of the best grown man body builders in the sport was very impressive. So at the age of 18, Heropul was about 200 pounds on stage and five foot 10. He would win four titles that year at the age of 18. He would win the Mr. North America, the Mr. Chicago Park District, the Mr. Tri State, and the Mr. Northern Indiana. And then right before he graduated high school in 1962, he would compete in the Mr. America again as a high schooler taking second at the Mr. America and winning the most muscular award at the Mr. America. So three months after graduating high school, would be when he won that Mr. Universe title that I mentioned earlier. So another interesting thing here is that Mr. Universe that he won in 1963. He was 19 years old and he beat Larry Scott. So Larry Scott was the guy that would beat him at the Olympian when the first Olympia ever in 1965. But as a teenager, Heropul had beaten him. So that was a very interesting thing. And again, goes to speak to how great of a body builder Heropul really was for that era. So as I mentioned before, he was the first African American ever to hold the title of the IPPB, Mr. America. And when he won that title, he was 20 years old. So by the age of 20, he had already won at the Mr. America and the Mr. Universe as well as four other titles before ever even competing in the Mr. Olympia. And I would say as far as his physique goes, the probably most standout body part that he had was probably his arms. I mean, his arm development was insane for that period of time. It's particularly his biceps. Now obviously it would turn out that there would be no match for the arms of Larry Scott. But still, for that period of time, this guy had incredible arms. And unfortunately, Heropul passed away back in 2014 about four years ago now. So he's no longer with us and I wanted to make a video kind of dedicated to him. I think I mentioned him briefly way back when I had maybe 20,000 subscribers, but I wanted to make a video. I'm going into full detail about his bodybuilding career because he was really an incredible bodybuilder for that era. So please give the video a thumbs up if you enjoyed it. === FILE: The Smallest Waist in Bodybuilding [S3vSZr8FGdw].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the Power Zone. This video I want to talk about a bodybuilder by the name of Brian Buchanan. Now there's so much talk today about guys with these big waste and bodybuilding. I don't think there's enough talk about guys that had the crazy small waste in bodybuilding. In my opinion, Brian Buchanan had proportionally the smallest waste in bodybuilding. So I'm not talking about in terms of sheer measurement in this smallest waste, even though he only had a 28 inch waste with an expanded chest of 57 inches, creating one of the greatest V-tapers ever. But proportionally, I don't think we've ever seen another bodybuilder that had a waste as small as he had with an upper body as big as he had, creating that waste to upper body ratio. That was just absolutely out of this world. Now if you want to talk about some of the greatest vacuum poses of all time, you've got to have Brian Buchanan in that conversation. Now granted Frank Zain had an amazing vacuum pose, but he didn't have nearly the upper body mass that Brian Buchanan had because not only did Brian Buchanan have this tiny waste, he was able to pull off an incredible vacuum pose. He had actually really big arms, really big chest, and pretty good lats as well to accompany this small waste. Creating possibly one of the greatest classic physics that we had ever seen. Now Brian Buchanan competed primarily in the 1980s, specifically he would hit his stride in the late 80s. Now unfortunately, we would only get the opportunity to see Brian Buchanan compete at the Mr. Olympia competition on two occasions in 1988 and 1989. So in 1988 he placed seventh at the Mr. Olympia in a 1989 he placed eighth, but 1988 I would say was his better of the two Olympia appearances, having what many would describe as the V-taper from hell. Probably the best V-taper on the Olympia stage, but really in terms of his overall impression on the Olympia he never did better than seventh, so that's probably why a lot of you guys have not heard of him. The reason why I think he didn't place very highly is because although he had this incredible upper body ratio, I don't think his legs were as good as the upper body, so I think his legs were certainly a lacking point, just in terms of overall size, but had he had bigger legs and maybe a little bit more overall muscle mass. You could have seen Brian Buchanan win a Mr. Olympia, but keep in mind during the time that he was competing at the Mr. Olympia in 1988 and 1989, these are both years that we would see Lee Haney win, and Lee Haney in my opinion was essentially just a bigger version of Brian Buchanan. I mean if you compare both Lee Haney and Brian Buchanan's front double-by-step with a vacuum pose, they look extremely similar, except for the fact that Lee Haney is just a little bit bigger than him. So when people say bodybuilding has a lot to do with illusion and creating this illusion of an X frame or a V-taper, I think Brian Buchanan was simply just the master of that. He was the embodiment of that illusion, having a waist of small as he did made his upper body look so much bigger, made his V-taper look that much crazier, and it even made his legs look bigger, despite the fact that they were actually not that big, having a waist that small going into the legs, made the legs look that much bigger. So despite the fact that Brian Buchanan did not have that much success within the IFB, he was very successful in the organization known as NABA, and as many of you already know NABA was basically the premier title and bodybuilding prior to the Mr. Olympia. The NABA Mr. Universe competition was the most sought after title prior to 1965, and Brian Buchanan would win that NABA Mr. Universe competition in 1984 prior to entering the IFBB, and then after leaving the IFBB, he would go back to NABA in 1995 and win the NABA Universe again. And then three years later he would come back to the IFB in 1998, placing 13th at the night of champions, then placing 9th at the Toronto Pro-Invitational. So I just wanted to share that with you guys. I'm sure a lot of people are getting tired of people talking about the biggest guts and bodybuilding today, and rather it'd be interesting to focus on one of the smallest guts of all time, or one of the smallest waist, you can't even call it a gut. === FILE: The man who invented the Bench Press [Lm0I_HgP0ME].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Next Time Empower. So I've got a pretty good body building history video for you guys today. So in this video we're going to throw it all the way back to the 1800s and talk about a guy by the name of George Hackensmith. So you talk about guys like Eugene Sandow that were true pioneers in body building. Now George Hackensmith was a true pioneer of strength sports, and particularly some of the exercises that we heavily utilize today, including the bench press and the Hack squat. So obviously the Hack squat named after Hackensmith. So the Hack squat as many of you may or may not know, it kind of looks like a variation of the deadlift where you have the bar placed behind your hamstrings and you're lifting it off the ground. And this was really first patented by George Hackensmith. Now another interesting thing about George Hackensmith is you was one of the earliest professional wrestlers, wrestling in a total of over 3000 professional wrestling matches and claiming he won every single one of them. Now another interesting fact here is George Hackensmith says in his book The Way to Live that he actually devised the word Hack squat from his own last name, the first part of it, the word Hack, which apparently originally came from and meant heel. So in the Hack squat, obviously the bar is starting at your heel. So that is where the name Hack squat came from. And there's also a speculation for you wrestling fans out there. You know the bad guy in pro wrestling is known as the heel and the good guy is known as the baby face. So some people say that the whole origin of heel meaning bad guy and professional wrestling actually came from George Hackensmith being a professional wrestler. Now probably the more well known lift that George Hackensmith is associated with beginning is the bench press. So some people might argue that there were rough versions of a bench press dating back to the Greco Roman times, which was really more kind of weighted pushups and focusing on chest exercises. But George Hackensmith was the first person to lay down with a barbell and press it over his chest. And it actually started out as a floor press. So he didn't lay on a bench. He laid flat on the floor and I'm going to press a barbell and he actually pressed 350 pounds the first time that he ever did that. And that's what really kick started the popularity of the bench press becoming what it is today. I'm there with obviously evolved to not just pressing from the floor but develop benches to bench press. And that's where the bench press movement really started with a George Hackensmith. Now naturally being a pioneer of the body building and you know really more powerlifting in the world over the course of his career. He set a lot of world records at the time and certain lifts. Most of the time being very obscure lifts including a 243 pound overhead press. Which he would actually improve upon and eventually overhead press 275 pounds, which again, we're talking about 1898 when he did this. So at the time that is a very impressive feat of strength. Now earlier in this video, I mentioned Eugene Sandow, who obviously is credited as holding the first ever body building competition. And he's also the man featured on the Mr. Olympia trophy, the Sandow trophy. Now the reason that's relevant is not only were they both pioneers of strength sports and body building, but they both competed around the same era. So as far as Feets of Strength go, Eugene Sandow was probably most well known for his one-handed overhead press. Now Eugene Sandow's record was 116 kilograms, one-handed press, which is the equivalent of about 225 pounds, and George Hackensman actually beat this record in 1899, where they 268.91 handed overhead press, or about 122 kilograms. So not only was Hackensman an innovator in terms of all these different movements that we still used today, and also a pretty impressive pro wrestler. But for that era, this guy was insanely strong. In fact, he was world record strong in most of his lifts. In fact, when he invented a hack squat, that became a world record. Number one, because it was the first hack squat. Number two, it was 187 pounds behind his back with bent knees. The first ever hack squat, that was a world record as well. And he would go on to claim multiple world records and various different lifts. A lot of obscure different things. But overall, this guy was a legend of Strength Sports. And even though this guy was competing and setting many of these world records back in the 1800s, he actually lived an extremely long life, and actually didn't pass away until 1968 at the age of 90 years old. I thought this would be a fascinating topic for a video. Number one, because this guy is an absolute legend. In number two, because this guy invented the bench press, man. I mean, this is a major milestone in Strength Sports history and bodybuilding history. Just in physical culture history, in general, the bench press is probably the most well-known of all the lifts. Typically, if you're a big muscular guy and you got in public and someone comes up to you, what is the question they're most likely to ask you? How much you bench? So George Hackensmith is the reason for that. So I hope you guys enjoyed the video. Please give a thumbs up if you did enjoy it, an strength and power signing out.

Not only that but there was a clear lack of abdominal separation in a key. So not only was his stomach distended but in many of the poses including the abs and thighs. He didn't really have that visible of abs. So even though his conditioning was good in other areas his midsection was still very problematic for him. Now from a sheer muscle mass standpoint I think a key certainly beats one. And just in terms of being the bigger guy. Again his legs are better. Arms chest. But again that conditioning is going to let him down. In particular what we're going to see here is when they turn around from the back. Now the problem with a key he does have a very dense back. But the problem is he has very high inserted lats. So in most of the back poses he almost has no lower back at all. No lower lats. Very little separation or detail in the lower back at all. Whereas one more l. has very low inserted lats. So the back poses he looks significantly better than a key Williams. I think the back poses in conditioning are what one this show for one more l. So I just wanted to clear that up for you guys. I think you know a key Williams looked tremendous. Best version of a key that we've ever seen. But I think before people start you know accusing the judges of getting it wrong and saying a key was just robbed blind. I mean you have to really know what you're actually talking about and know how to actually judge a bodybuilding competition because just being a bigger guy with decent conditioning as I've said before isn't going to win you the show. Juan was better conditioned. His back was better. His V-Taper was better. His midsection was better. Although his legs were weaker than a keen certainly weaker than a keen by a long shot. There are a lot of other areas where Juan was more polished and better than a keen and that's what gave Juan the victory. === FILE: When Dorian Yates lost to the Giant Killer [EKl-3cTbEeI].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the Power Zone. This video I want to talk about the 1990 Night of Champions. This particular year's Night of Champions was a very important year for bodybuilding because it was really a show that was really exemplifying the whole giant killer mentality of a smaller guy with better conditioning, better proportions, better symmetry, beating a much larger guy with more muscle mass, but having maybe not the conditioning or maybe not the proportions that these smaller guys had. So in 1990 you had Dorian Yates competing in his very first pro show ever the Night of Champions. So at Dorian's biggest he weighed roughly 265 pounds on stage, but obviously in 1990 we were not seeing the biggest version of Dorian yet. So in 1990 he was probably a lot closer to about 250 pounds on stage, but still significantly out sizing two of the guys that placed on either side of him that night. So Dorian placed second at the 1990 Night of Champions. He lost to a guy by the name of Momo Benaziza. So Momo Benaziza was about 5 foot 2 inches tall or 158 centimeters and he weighed around 185 pounds, typically no more than 187 pounds or 85 kilograms. That's how he earned his nickname, the Killer of Giants, specifically at this 1990 show was where he earned that nickname. So Muhammad Benaziza really made a statement at this 1990 Night of Champions. He had an insane back. He was shredded to the bone, his conditioning was on another level again to the point where he out conditioned a guy that was 70 pounds heavier than him. Even though Dorian was new to the pro scene at this show and this was his first show ever, make no mistake about it. Dorian definitely made a giant statement at this show when people saw how big he was. I'm just the overall potential that this guy had. And Dorian came out of seemingly nowhere, but even with that wow factor in the crazy size that Dorian brought, Muhammad Benaziza was just so good. Dorian cannot beat him. In fact, 1990 Muhammad Benaziza was arguably one of the best versions of Muhammad Benaziza we would see. During that year, he won 5 Grand Prix Competition. He won 5 IFBB Pro Shows and the Knight of Champions. So he won 6 Pro Shows in one year, which is an astounding accomplishment for anybody builder to even win 6 Pro Shows during their entire career. Now unfortunately just two years later after beating Dorian at that 1990 Night of Champions, Muhammad Benaziza would pass away at the age of 33 years old. In the even sadder part about that is that 1992 was also a very good year from Muhammad Benaziza placing second at the Arnold Classic winning 2 Grand Prix and placing 5th at the 1992 Mr Olympia. So while a lot of people may not have heard of Muhammad Benaziza, it's probably because his career was cut so short by that early death because he was on the fast track to doing some great things in bodybuilding. He was a very high place and again, he beat the 6th time Olympia Dorian Yates while his career was still just getting off the ground. But if we go back to that 1999 of Champions for a second and the reason why I call this the show of the giant killers, there's another bodybuilder whose nickname was also the giant killer competing at this show, Danny Padilla. And we saw a very impressive version of Danny Padilla at this show. Now Danny Padilla wasn't even smaller bodybuilder than Muhammad Benaziza standing 5 foot two inches tall and weighing only between 165 pounds and 175 pounds on stage or between 74.8 and 79.4 kilograms. So 175 at his biggest arguably maybe 180 in some cases. But the fascinating thing here was that he almost beat Dorian Yates as well at the 1999 of Champions. So you had Muhammad Benaziza in first, Dorian Yates in second and an extremely impressive Danny Padilla in third at the 1999 of Champions. And a lot of people would even argue that Danny Padilla should have beaten Dorian Yates at that 1999 of Champions. Myself could be included in that group because I think you could make a strong argument for Danny Padilla being second there because I personally believe 1990 Danny Padilla at that night of Champions was one of the best and fullest and roundest Danny Padilla's we had ever seen while maintaining an extremely, you know, just razor crisp conditioning. So could you guys imagine if this mass monster Dorian Yates 250 pounds came out of nowhere and was beaten by two guys weighing under 190 pounds on stage? What a statement that would have been for bodybuilding in terms of, you know, this is what we care about. We care about proportions. We care about symmetry. We care about conditioning. We don't care about, you know, just some giant guy coming out of nowhere and winning just because he's giant. That would have been a massive statement for bodybuilding and it really was. The fact that that guy placed third and then he had Muhammad Mu'awin and Dorian was in between the two was still a pretty big statement of Dorian saying, you know, it's time for you to go back to the drawing board and work on some things and Dorian certainly did that. Because just two years later Dorian would win his first of six Mr Olympia titles, but that would not be the end of Dorian being challenged by a much smaller guy because that same year that Dorian won his first Olympia, you had Leela Brada and third and Sean Ray and fourth. Two guys significantly smaller than Dorian, but still comparing very favorably with Dorian, again speaking to the fact that size isn't everything because we all know Dorian did not have the prettiest physique, but he did have a massive physique and because of that you had guys like Leela Brada and Sean Ray constantly nipping at his heels more so Sean Ray than Leela Brada. Because of course you had Sean Ray placing second to Dorian in 1994, 1996 and third and 1997 behind Nasser and Dorian. So again, throughout Dorian's career even though he was this crazy mass monster, you still had these giant killers coming after him constantly from day one at his pro-day view. And again the funny thing was, man, one of Sean Ray's nicknames was the giant killer as well. So the 1990s was certainly the era of the giant killers and was certainly a good era to be a body builder if you were a smaller guy because at that time judges were rewarding conditioning, proportions, symmetry and they were saying sizes and everything, which is not really what we see so much today with the IFPB or NPC even. They seem to be looking for the much bigger guy and size seems to be a really dominant factor in determining Olympia placing. So the 1990s again, a great era in body building. Let me know what you guys think in the comment section below about the 1990 night of champions. Thank you guys for watching the video and please give it a thumbs up if you enjoyed it. Nick strength and power signing out.

=== FILE: Why do Men's Gymnasts have such Big Biceps？ [DftQl3cVKMA].txt ===

Alright, what's going on you guys? Nick here with Nick's on the Power. So one of my subscribers actually sent me an interesting topic that I've never really thought too much about before, and that is the men's Olympic gymnastics team, specifically, they're in sane bicep development. So personally, I've never been the biggest fan of the Olympics. I never really watched them or go out of my way to watch them. So I certainly wasn't very familiar with the men's Olympic gymnastics team, specifically the one this guy was mentioning was the one from 2012. When he gave me this topic and he asked me this question on why they have these extremely developed biceps, I googled some of the pictures he was talking about of some of the athletes that he had mentioned, specifically Jonathan Horton, Jacob Dalton, and a guy named Brandon and Wynn. And of course all of these guys had pretty muscular physics, I mean they're Olympic athletes, they're high level athletes. Particularly the guy that sent me this question he was right. All of these guys actually did have extremely developed biceps to the point where they were disproportionate to the rest of their body. I mean these guys, they had huge biceps. So the subscriber that mentioned this topic, he asked me two questions specifically. Number one, why do these guys have such developed biceps and number two, would it be who a bodybuilder to include some sort of gymnastic routine in their training if they wanted to build bigger biceps? I thought this was a very fascinating question. After I saw the photos of these guys that he was talking about and I realized, okay, there might be something to this. These guys do have extremely developed biceps. So what is it that they're doing in their gymnastics routines or gymnastics training that makes them have this extreme bicep development? So I started looking through the list of gymnastic events that these athletes go through, both the men and the women. Typically what I think of when I think of gymnastics is the floor routine when they're doing flips and stuff. They're judged on their landing, how many flips they do, how artistic they're routine is. And I also think of the balance beam. But one thing that I hadn't really thought of or didn't really realize was gymnastics was an event called the Still Rings. And this is actually something that you see in a lot of gyms, especially CrossFit gyms, there are two rings suspended from a wire cable on the ceiling. And typically in a gym, you're going to see people doing pull ups on these. So this is what got my attention. So obviously a pull up is going to activate your biceps as well as your lats. So I said, okay, let me go ahead and look at some of these athletes. This guy had mentioned Jonathan Horton, Jacob Dalton and Brandon Winn. All of these guys, if you look at their career and their accomplishments, they all excelled in the still rings. All these guys that had very well developed biceps seem to also do very well in the still rings. So I went ahead and looked up what a still rings routine really consisted of. And I've got to say, man, when I watched one of these routines, I was extremely impressed by what these athletes actually do. And it's really a whole lot of balance and really raw strength, specifically though, the arm strength. What they'll do is they'll pull themselves up in a weird position. And they'll statically hold their bodies in that position just exclusively, straining the muscle to hold the body weight there. And it's very fascinating. Now the main thing that I noticed after watching some of these routines is the number one muscle that seems to be activated here is going to be the biceps. I mean, as they pull themselves up into each static position, they start from the base. So they start from the bottom. And the biceps appear to be the main muscle that really initiate the transition from each static hold to another. And one of the poses that's mandatory for all these guys it seems is to pull themselves up into a crucifix pose with their arms fully extended either side of their body. I'm holding their entire body weight with their arms out to the side, which is very impressive. There's a lot of arms and delts involved in that. But some of these guys, what they'll do is basically a front double bicep and just statically hold their body weight in a front double bicep pose, which I found to be very impressive. So I would imagine if you're a guy that specializes in this still rings event, probably the majority of your training is doing pull-ups or bicep movements on those rings. That's why these guys have such big biceps. Now, a lot of these guys just have big arms in general. And the other exercise or the other routine that I found to be responsible for this is something called the pommel whore. So essentially what this is is, it's like a balance beam with two handles on it. And essentially the entire time, these guys are using their hands. I don't think their legs can touch the balance beam. So they're supporting their entire body weight on their hands and arms, the entire routine. And using momentum and triceps strength pretty much to move their body around. So that pommel whore's routine to me looks like it's pretty much exclusively triceps in arm strength. Maybe a little bit of shoulders. But aside from momentum, most of the weight and most of the pressure is going to be on these guys as triceps when they're doing this pommel whore's. So that would be another reason. So a lot of these guys in addition to their gymnastic routines also have a body building routine to go with that. So it's not like they're exclusively doing just rings. It's not like they don't go to the gym at all. And they're just going to the gymnastic training center and just doing rings all day. They actually do have a supplemental body building routine where they actually lift weights and train with weights to achieve these physics. So I wanted to dispel kind of that myth that these guys are achieving their physics exclusively through these gymnastic movements because that's not the case. I do think an exercise like the rings. If you're training that constantly every single day working on your biceps strength, they do this, you know, still rings exercise. That's certainly going to contribute to the size of your biceps. But every single one of these guys is in the gym doing weight training or some kind of body building or strength routine aside from just the gymnastic routine. So I thought it was an interesting topic. I'm actually going to start incorporating some still ring cool ups into my training routine. Instead of just doing regular pull ups, I think it would be beneficial to incorporate some of these where it seems to activate the biceps a lot more than it would the last. So let me know which guys think in the comments section below. I hope you guys found this video interesting and please give it a thumbs up if you enjoyed it. Next strength and power signing out.

So last night on Instagram, Phil Heath's girlfriend posted a video showing all of Phil Heath's sandout trophies and medals. In the caption of this video, was I keep seeing fellow Olympia winners of other divisions, calling themselves a Mr. Olympia of their division. I'm going to help you all out. This is what Mr. Olympia gets for winning the Mr. Olympia competition. If you're not an open-class bodybuilder, winning the Mr. Olympia open-heavyweight division, then you are not Mr. O. So if you compete at the Mr. Olympia in September and you win your division, that just means you're the champion of that division. You're not Mr. Olympia and if you think you are, I kindly suggest you go check your trophy wall. If a sandout isn't there, then it should help you with the confusion of using that title that isn't yours. It's disrespectful to my man's hard work and the 12 other Mr. Olympias who stood on that stage. The comments on this post are turned off and this isn't up for discussion or debate. Well, I disagree with that part because the comments are on in this video and I want you guys to debate this in the comment section below. Now the reason why I found this interesting is because it only applies to really four other men out there. You got Flex Lewis who is the five time to 12 Olympia champion. You've got Brianna Andesley who is the current Classic physique Olympia champion and you also have Danny Hester who won the Classic physique Olympia last year. And finally the person who this is probably directed at is Jeremy Boindia who is currently the four time men's physique Olympia champion. Now even though this is probably directed at Jeremy because he has the most or he's been in the middle of the most controversy lately, it does really apply to all four of these men. She guys might be a little surprised with my opinion here because I do actually agree with her to an extent. There's only one division at the Olympia competition that is competing for the Mr. Olympia title. That's not really up for debate. There's only one division where you win that title. There's only one Mr. Olympia title and that goes to the winner of men's open body building. It's been that way since 1965. That is the Mr. Olympia. Technically speaking, every other category at the Mr. Olympia is just a division at the Olympia. If you win Classic physique, you won Classic physique at the Olympia. You didn't become Mr. Olympia, you won Classic physique at the Olympia. If you win men's physique, you win men's physique at the Olympia. None of those divisions are being earned the title of Mr. Olympia. That's just how it is. So from a technical standpoint, she's right. Nobody else is earning that title of Mr. Olympia. However, I will disagree that when these guys say, I am the 2012 Mr. Olympia or I am the Classic physique Mr. Olympia or I'm the men's physique Mr. Olympia. If they call themselves Mr. Olympia, but specify which category they won. I don't really see a problem with that. I don't think that's disrespectful at all. Especially when you're trying to explain it to the general public or the mainstream. I won my division at the Mr. Olympia. Doesn't sound quite as good as I'm the Classic physique Mr. Olympia. However, there are a couple guys that she could be referring to, including Jeremy Boyndia, that I have seen refer to themselves as simply Mr. Olympia. No other title, no other explanation, no men's physique, no Classic physique. I am Mr. Olympia or Mr. Olympia in their bio. And that actually does include both Classic physique Mr. Olympia. They both have that in their bio as well. They don't have Classic physique Olympia. They just have Mr. Olympia. Now even though I do slightly agree with Shari here, I do want to play Devil's Advocate. So women's bodybuilding, female bodybuilding. They're used to only be one Miss Olympia. And that was the winner of the female bodybuilding division at the Olympia. That's how it always was up until female bodybuilding went away. The guys might remember Dana Lynn Bailey when she won the Olympia. Everybody called her Miss Olympia. No one had a problem with it. Everyone referred to Dana Lynn Bailey as Miss Olympia. However, she didn't win the female bodybuilding division. She won the Women's Physique Division. So I just wanted to throw that into conversation before everyone's like, oh, that's just disrespectful and dumb. I want to remind everybody that I've seen pretty much everybody calling Dana Lynn Bailey Miss Olympia. And no one was complaining about her taking that title. When technically female bodybuilding is the only division that was supposed to get that title. So let me know what you guys think in the comments section below. Please give this video a thumbs up if you enjoyed it. Next time in power, signing out.
